int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"In this program strategies arefirsttaught "by themselves" before they are practiced in combination with each other (Pressley et al., 1992). The strategies are taught in the fol- lowing cumulative order. In thefirsttwo lessons students learn to predict the future content of a text. Then during the follow- ing two lessons the students learn to clarify. During the inte- gration lessons all previously learned strategies are practiced in combination with each other. The third strategy is summa- rizing (7th and 8th lessons). During the 9th and 10th lessons, the focus is on summarizing again, but the two previously learned strategies are trained as well. Finally, the strategy of questioning is taught. [¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"strategies were trained through direct instruction and reciprocal teaching"
"the teacher explains and models the strategies out loud after the group has listened to a text pre- sented on audiotape or videotape. In the application phase of each lesson, the strategies are practiced through reciprocal teaching. A student is appointed as discussion leader of the group of 4 children. After listening to a text the child executes one or more strategies. The other students are then stimulated to react. "
"After discussion, another student takes over the role of discussion leader. In order to help the students with applying the strategies properly, cards with questions that rep- resent the strategies serve as reminders during the lesson.[¬e]"']

['Page 6:
[¬s]"During the first day the students were introduced to the study and then given 35 min\xad utes to either complete the vocabulary look-up activity or the SFA activity. The remainder of the class period and 15 minutes of the second day were spent silently reading the passage. During the second day 10 minutes were spent either reviewing the looked-up vocabulary words or reviewing the relationship chart completed during the SFA activity."
"In the SFA activity the students and teacher completed a rela\xad tionship chart. This chart listed the major concepts presented in the passages across the top and listed the related vocabulary down the side. First the teacher briefly explained the major concepts and each vocabulary word. Then the students, through discussion led .by the teacher, rated each vocabulary word in relation to each major concept as having: a) a positive relationship, b) a negative relationship, c) unrelated, or d) don't know the relationship. Students in the SFA[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"condition were encouraged to read the passage to verify their ratings and clarify any relationships that were rated as don't know.[¬e]"']

int_training_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]" During the school year, the four university students underwent training at Tel Aviv University for their role as student-mediators. Each pair of student-mediators working on the same program (either joint reading or joint writing) attended separate 1-h weekly meetings with the co- ordinator. In these meetings, the student-mediators shared their experiences from the previous week and learned the contents and goals of the coming week\x92s sessions, including the connections to the earlier sessions. During the weekly supervision meetings, the students received printed one-page guidelines for each of the upcoming week\x92s sessions, as well as the necessary materials (games, books, stickers, etc.). Students also talked about the materials they would have to prepare for these sessions (printing certain words, clipping words from newspapers, bringing costumes for a show, etc.) and discussed possible dif\x1eculties.[¬e]"']
int_dur_info: 66 sessions, 2 sessions a week = 33 weeks of teaching

int_name_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"The Start Making a Reader Today (SMART) tutoring program[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"Students are designated for participation in SMART by their teachers, who are asked to choose students who they believe are at risk for reading failure. Students attend tutoring sessions for 30 minutes twice a week throughout the school year, and they may take home two books each month to keep for themselves for home reading. Popular books to read and take home in first grade in- clude The Very Hungry Caterpillar (Carle, 1984), and The Grouchy Ladybug (Carle, 1996). Popular books in second grade include A Pocket for Corduroy (Freeman, 1980) and any number of books from the Arthur series (e.g., Arthur Babysits and Arthur Accused, Brown, [¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"tart Making a Reader Today (SMART) is a volun- teer tutoring program in Oregon to help kinder- garten through second grade students learn to read (www.mytownnet.com/projects/OR/smart/ smart.htm; Oregon Children\'s Foundation, 1992, 1998). It specifically focuses on those children who, according to their teachers, are having difficulty learning the[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"Volunteers can be trained either in the fall before tutoring has begun or any time during the school year. An initial training session is held at the beginning of the year at a central location, such as the school district cen- tral office. The training lasts 1-2 hours, during which 30-40 minutes is devoted to actual reading strategies vol- unteers can use with students. The remaining time goes to orientation and discussion of logistical and administra- tive issues, school rules, and safety protocols. Training emphasizes the importance of reading to students and having students read. Volunteers are encouraged to try to increase students\' interests in reading, to make the tutor- ing sessions fun, and to ask students questions about the material they read. After the initial 30-minute training ses- sion, volunteers are free to begin working with children on their own, and most receive no additional trainin"\n"SMART volunteers may also sign up to be tutors af- ter the school year begins. In this case, training is con- ducted at the school in impromptu sessions organized by the coordinator. A common training activity is for the co- ordinator to model a few strategies during a reading ses- sion with a student before the volunteer takes over. int_desc_ht:
['Page 10:
[¬s]"Lesson 1: Introduction/self-questioning. The objective of Lesson 1 was to teach students self-questioning as a first step in comprehension monitoring. The concept of self-questioning was introduced by presenting to the students the fictional figure Clark Canine-Super Reporter (CC/SR). CC/SR was modeled after similar meta- phors Paris and his colleagues developed for their Informed Strategies for Learning metacognitive instructional program (Paris, 1985; Paris et al., 1984). CC/SR, who appeared throughout the 10 TA group lessons, was presented as a special kind of reporter who interviewed writers. The students were taught to view the role of a reporter (one who interviews people) as being analogous to the role of a reader (one who interviews writers). The students were asked to think of themselves as Pup Reporters, novice writer-interviewers led by CC/SR, whose job it was to interview (i.e., ask questions of) writers whose stories they read. CC/SR was displayed as a large cutout (a canine dressed to look like Clark Kent, i.e., Super- man). A chart that compared how reporters and readers are alike was also intro- duced in Lesson 1. The first pair of items on this chart, which were affixed to the chart during the lesson, indicated that reporters and readers are alike in that they both conduct interviews by asking writers/people questions. Additional ways in which readers and reporters are alike were added to the chart as other comprehen- sion monitoring and correction strategies were introduced in subsequent lessons. For example, in Lesson 2, the two following statements were added to the chart: (a) "Reporters get information from the person they interview and from what they know already" and (b) "Readers get information from the writer and from what[¬e]"', 'Page 11:
[¬s]"they know already." Instruction and application in how to question a writer oc- curred through the guided reading of the basal story used in Lesson 1. Lesson 2: Sources of information. Using a modified form of Raphael's (1982) question-answer relationship strategy, students were taught that information can come from ideas in the story and from ideas a student may already possess (i.e., after Pearson & Johnson's, 1978, notion of textually explicit and scriptally implicit information). Lesson 3: TA introduction: Is the story making sense? Students were intro- duced to the notion of thinking aloud as they read by being taught to: (a) read short text sections, (b) stop periodically and say out loud what their thoughts were about the story, (c) ask " I s this making sense?", and (d) respond to this question. Lesson 4: TA review and extension. This was a cumulative review of the first three lessons. Lesson 5: Predicting, reading, and verifying. Students were taught to use a predict-read-verify strategy (Baumann, 1991); they expressed their predictions and their evaluations of them through think aloud. Lesson 6: Understanding unstated information. Students were taught to infer unstated information in a story according to a simplified version of the inference categories recommended by Johnson and Johnson (1986); they used think aloud to verbalize what a writer omitted, drawing from story and experience clues. Lesson 7: Retelling a story. Retelling was presented as a think-aloud strategy for helping a reader to understand and remember a story. Lesson 8: Rereading and reading on. Students were instructed to stop periodi- cally while reading and ask themselves, " I s this story making sense?" When they responded " n o " to this question, they were asked to employ one of two correction strategies to help them clarify meaning, either a rereading strategy or a read-on- and-withhold-judgment strategy. Lessons 9 and 10: TA/comprehension monitoring application. The final two lessons consisted of review instruction and guided practice of the content of Les- sons 1-8.[¬e]"', 'Page 12:
[¬s]"DRTA instruction. DRTA as taught to the children in this experiment consisted of four steps: (a) Students made initial predictions about the story from the title and any pictures on the title page, and predictions were recorded on the chalk board; (b) students read one-third to one-half of the story and evaluated their initial predictions using the scheme r = t r u e , F = false, / T = p a r t l y true, P F = partly false, and NM=not mentioned; (c) students made additional predictions; and (d) steps b and c were repeated once or twice more, depending upon the length of the story.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]"The purpose of TA instruction was to promote students\' com- prehension monitoring and self-correction abilities. The TA training was viewed as a vehicle for helping students to acquire control over these abilities; that is, think aloud was a means to an endÑimproved comprehension monitoring abil- ityÑnot the end itself.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:\n[¬s]" the purpose of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of explicit instruction in a think-aloud procedure as a means to promote young stu- dents\' comprehension monitoring abilities relative to the DRTA and DRA proce- dures.[¬e]"']

[¬s]"Preexperimentalgroup differences. To determine whether the four treatment groups were generally equiva\xad lent at the preexperimental stage, a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was conducted for each pretest. Results indicated that the groups did not differ on Pretest 1, F(3, 84) = .197, p < .898, or on Pretest 2, F(3, 84) = .385, p < .764. This suggests that the four participating classrooms in the quasiexperiment did not differ prior to intervention in general vocabulary knowledge (Pretest 1, Degrees of Word Meaning) or in knowledge of a sample of target vocabulary (Pretest 2, Lesson and Transfer Words).[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"For Text Talk, Rich Instruction was de- veloped for several words from each story. The vocabulary instruction occurred after a story had been read, discussed, and con- cluded. Instruction took place after reading because the goal for teaching the words was to enhance general vocabulary develop- ment rather than comprehension of the story at hand. If we judged that any unfa- miliar words were needed for story com- prehension, the teacher brieﬂy explained the meanings of those words during read- ing."
"As an illustration of the kind of instruc- tion provided, consider the vocabulary in- struction from The Bremen Town Musicians (Plume, 1998), a story about a series of aban- doned animals who set off to make their musical fortune. The words feast, exhausted, and cautiously were selected from the story. The following explains the way feast was taught. The words in quotations are from the script that teachers received for the in- struction and illustrate how the information was provided to students. • First, the word was contextualized for its role in the story: “In the story, it said that the animals found the robbers’ ta- ble full of good things to eat, and so they had a feast.” • Next, the meaning of the word was ex- plained: “A feast is a big special meal with lots of delicious food.” • The children were asked to repeat the word so that they could create a pho- nological representation of it: “Say the word with me: feast.” • Examples in contexts other than the one used in the story were provided: “People usually have a feast on a hol- iday or to celebrate something special. We all have a feast on Thanksgiving Day.” • Children made judgments about ex- amples: “Which would be a feast: eat- ing an ice cream cone or eating at a big table full of all kinds of food? Why?” • Children were asked to construct their own examples: “If you wanted to eat a feast, what kinds of food would you want?” • The word’s phonological and mean- ing representations were reinforced: “What’s the word that means a big special meal?”"
"In addition to introducing words in the manner shown above, teachers were asked to reinforce the words on subsequent days.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"For example, all teachers kept charts of the words from several stories posted on the wall. If children heard or used one of the words, a tally mark was placed next to the word. Teachers attempted to use the words in regular classroom activities.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"Young students’ thinking capabilities are advanced compared to their reading abili- ties at kindergarten and ﬁrst grade. Text Talk takes advantage of this and provides them with opportunities for rich language development through discussion of narra- tives that are more complex than those they could read on their own.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:\n[¬s]" Given our goal of promoting the construction of meaning from linguistic content, we sought books in which the linguistic content was primary, that is, the books did not rely too heavily on pictures to communicate the story. A ﬁ- nal criterion in consideration of construct- ing meaning was that stories exhibit an event structure rather than a series of situ- ations, a format that is sometimes used in books for young children. A related goal of using Text Talk was to develop vocabulary by taking advantage of the sophisticated vocabulary found in these trade books by teaching and encouraging oral use of several words from a story.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"We introduced Text Talk to the four ex- perimental teachers in the fall of the school year through a 3-hour workshop that ex- plained the approach and the motivations for its development. Materials were pro- vided to teachers in the form of 36 books at each grade level, with questions to frame the text interactions, and vocabulary activ- ities.[¬e]"']
int_dur_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]". The instructional intervention com- prised the vocabulary materials from books that were scheduled to be used over a 10- week period near the end of the school year[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"In the experimental classrooms, Text Talk was the daily read-aloud.[¬e]"']
int_leng_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]" Study 1, only initial instruction was provided, although teachers were asked to use the words in class and to prompt the children to use them. Thus, we undertook Study 2 to determine the extent to which increased instruction would en- hance learning.[¬e]"']
int_leng_info: Text talk was conducted daily in one lesson, therefore the session would have been under 1 hour long.

Thus, we decided to include the additional 13 students in the study, giving us 98 participants.[¬e]"']

int_training_ht: ['Page 13:\n[¬s]" 40 min of training in verbalizing their thoughts while reading aloud. Training was admin- istered to subjects in randomized groups of 6 to 8. It included description and modeling of each of the four target strategies described in Study 1, as well as 15 other strategic and nonstrategic behaviors identified in that study-for instance, imagery statements, associating information with pre- vious experience, and expressing personal reactions. Training also included supervised practice in thinking aloud while reading, with the experimenter encouraging verbalization of everything read and verbaliza- tion of all thoughts.[¬e]"']

int_name_info: PVRS Powerful Vocabulary for Reading Success
int_desc_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]"The four vocabulary-building clusters that were taught in this experimental study are described below: 1. Vocabulary Building Cluster 1 taught students how to think about the part of speech that a word serves in a sentence, and how to use context clues as strategies to learn the meaning of words that appear frequently in our language. 2. Vocabulary Building Cluster 2 taught students how to recognize when a word is affixed or has distinct, morphological units. For these words, students were taught to divide unknown words into prefixes, roots, and suffixes. Then students were taught to add the meanings of parts within this word together to derive its meaning. 3. Vocabulary Building Cluster 3 taught students how to identify the meaning of content-specific words. Students learned that many long, unfamiliar words that they have not seen frequently will most often have a meaning that is related to the particular content area and theme of the paragraph in which the unknown content-area word appears. Students are also taught how to connect the meanings of known content-area words to the possible specific object, event, phenomenon, etc. to which the unknown word must refer by relat - ing all meanings from all other content-specific words to the unknown word. The unknown word will contain a meaning that describes a unique aspect of the theme not portrayed by the other content-specific words in that paragraph. 4. Vocabulary Building Cluster 4 taught students to use the unusual letter or sound combination of a word as a signal that the wordÕs meaning has to be memorized, as it likely has an unusual word history or is derived from a foreign language. Students were taught to create their own personalized mnemonic device to learn this unusual wordÕs meaning.[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: First, students need to be taught specific word-learning strategies through teacher modeling and repeated practice. Second, they need to learn high-utility vocabulary words through engaging tasks, repetition, and multiple exposures. int_name_ht: ['Page 18:\n[¬s]"Language experience methods The language experience approach to teaching beginning reading attempts to bring the communication or language arts skills (speaking, listening, writing, and reading) together as a unit. Accord\xad ing to R. V. Allen (1964, p. 60): “The ‘togetherness’ of skill develop\xad ment makes possible the continuing use of each child’s own experi\xad ence background and thinking as he grows toward reading maturity.”[¬e]"']
int_name_info: Language experience approach page 22-   Overall the paper is about Cooperative Research Program in First-Grade Reading Instruction.
int_desc_ht:
['Page 18:
[¬s]"The language experience approach to teaching beginning reading attempts to bring the communication or language arts skills (speaking, listening, writing, and reading) together as a unit.[¬e]"', 'Page 19:
[¬s]" Allen states: “Utilization of the child’s language as a basis of reading instruction results in a high degree of independence in writing and reading” (1964, p. 63).[¬e]"', 'Page 42:
[¬s]"A fourth treatment group was labeled Language Experience. A basic element of this instructional method is that the child’s own writing serves as a medium of instruction. The child’s first stories are dictated to the teacher who acts as the recorder. As soon as he is able, the pupil writes his own stories and shares them with the teacher. During the individual conferences between pupil and teacher, he is helped to recognize the commonality between the words he writes and speaks and he develops the skills necessary for reading. This approach, then, ordinarily utilizes far fewer highly structured instructional ma\xad terials than do most instructional programs. In addition, vocabulary control is viewed as being in the language itself and in the language background of each child. The pupil learns to read the words necessary for him to use in writing. One of the major instructional tasks in this method is to engender a stimulating language environment.[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: Language experience method brings speaking, listening, writing and reading together as a unit.   compare 27 individual studies, different approaches to teach first-grade pupils how to read

int_name_info: Semantic-Feature Analysis (SFA, Anders & Bos 1986, Bos & Anders, 1987)
int_desc_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"During the first day, the students were introduced to the study and given 35 minutes to complete either the DM ac\xad tivity or the SFA activity. Students spent the remainder of the class period and 15 minutes of the second class period read\xad ing the passage. During the second class period, 10 minutes were also spent either reviewing the words and their definitions (DM condition) or reviewing the rela\xad tionship chart (SFA condition). During the remainder of the period, the students took the comprehension test and com\xad pleted the topic interest assessment."\n"Semantic Feature Analysis Condi\xad tion. The SFA experimental condition involved the students and the teacher- researcher discussing and completing the relationship chart in an effort to activate and instantiate students\' prior knowl\xad edge and predict relationships between new and old knowledge as represented by the concepts and vocabulary pre\xad sented in the relationship chart. The SFA procedure (Anders & Bos, 1986b; Bos & Anders, 1987) was followed, with a copy of the chart given to each student and reproduced on the board or a trans\xad parency. The name of the chart and each important idea (see Figure 1) were in\xad troduced by the teacher-researcher. Depending upon the students\' level of prior knowledge, a definition was either generated by the students or provided by the teacher-researcher. Students were encouraged to share their knowledge by providing examples based on their prior knowledge. Next, each important vo\xad cabulary item was introduced using the same procedure. Once a definition was generated for the vocabulary, the students were asked to predict the rela\xad tionship between the vocabulary and each of the important ideas. Each rela\xad tionship was rated as having: (a) a positive relationship ( + ) ; (b) a negative relationship ( - ) ; (c) no relationship (0); or (d) an unknown relationship (?). Discussion, including justification for the prediction, was elicited by the teacher-researcher. When consensus was reached, the rating was recorded in the appropriate box on the student and class charts. Once the chart was com\xad pleted, students were instructed to read the passage to confirm predictions and to clarify unknown relationships. After reading, the relationship chart was re\xad viewed and discussed. During the discus\xad sion, students clarified relationships previously rated as unknown and mod\xad ified relationships disconfirmed in the text.[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: High School students with learning disabilities had two 90 minute sessions on reading comprehension with social studies text.  In the SFA condition students completed a relationship chart. In the control conditino they used the dictionary to write definitions and sentences.

int_desc_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"instructional model designed to help students identified as learning disabled comprehend and learn content area concepts"
"n interactive model for text comprehension and content learning.[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]" an interactive model for text comprehension and content area learning focused specifically on learning disabled students[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]" an interactive model for text comprehension and content learning"
" It is interactive in two ways. First, the comprehension process is assumed to be constructive: it is a process in which readers use cognitive and metacognitive strategies to interact with information presented in the text, their hypotheses about the text meaning, and their current background knowledge. Thus, instructional strategies compatible with this model provide students opportunities for developing and employing cognitive and metacognitive strategies."
" learning is enhanced when the teacher and students engage in dialogues designed to discuss and organize concepts and to discuss and demonstrate strategic knowledge. An interactive dialogue encourages cooperative knowledge sharing because during the instructional dialogue both the teacher and students share their knowledge concerning content and strategies.[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"Semantic mapping uses a relationship map or web. The concepts are listed and then the teacher and students make predictions as to how the concepts can be arranged to represent the relationships among the concepts. In a hierarchical map the superordinate concept could be placed in an oval at the top of the map. The coordinate concepts would be placed in ovals underneath the superordinate concept with each coordinate concept connected to the superordinate concept with a line. Underneath each coordinate concept, the subordinate concepts could be placed in ovals and again connected with lines.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]" the interactive strategies (semantic feature analysis, semantic mapping, and semantic/syntactic feature analysis) were found to be more effective than instruction emphasizing definitions"\n" instructional models for promoting text comprehension in content area subjects.[¬e]"']

The staff development included feedback during practice sessions and feedback on videotaped instruction.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"Children were randomly assigned to three groups
and given pre- and posttests. Treatment was a shared reading experience; other groups had nor\xad
mal instruction"
"The treated group participated with their regular teacher in shared reading experiences
with predictable books. The control group proceeded with normal instruction that emphasized
units and learning centers.[¬e]"', 'Page 52:
[¬s]"The framework for the development of objectives
in the experimental group exposed to shared reading experi\xad
ences was derived from the three-dimensional model developed
by Holdaway (1979). Areas included discovery, exploration,
and independent experience and expression.[¬e]"', 'Page 53:
[¬s]"Examination of "discovery" revealed an introduction of a
new book in the listening situation with maximum participation
in predictable, repetitive structure. Objectives included:
to provide an enjoyable story; to induce a desire to return to
the book on subsequent days; and to encourage participation by
inducing children to chime in on repetitive sections, possible
outcomes, engage in suitable expressive activities, and to
suggest an obvious word."
"The next consideration, when applicable, was that of
"exploration," which consisted of re-readings for familiariza\xad
tion and teaching. Increasing unison participation is natural
to this re-experience. Objectives included: to deepen
understanding and responses; to help children become aware of
the special structures of the story; and to teach relevant
reading strategies in relation to the text."
"For this investigation, "independent experience and
expression" revolved around independent retrieval of the
experience in reading or reading-like ways by individuals or
small groups. Objectives included: to provide opportunities
for independent reading by individuals or very small groups;
to encourage the development of self-correction through the
use of familiar language models; to encourage expressive
activities so that children would identify more fully with the
story and internalize the language as a permanent part of
their competence (See Appendix C).[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 16:
[¬s]"etermining whether or not a specific teaching strategy
within one curriculum area in Head Start centers could enhance
children's knowledge was the major purpose. Specifically, the
goal was to ascertain if there were differences in responses
of Head Start children to concepts about print and story
structure following participating in shared reading experi\xad
ences with predictable books.[¬e]"', 'Page 19:
[¬s]"Holdaway (1979) explained that the concept behind shared
book experience procedures as displayed in the bedtime story
experience centers on developmental learning. Holdaway
proposed that children learn the spoken language and other
developmental concepts when bedtime stories are read to them."
"In depicting the characteristics of the shared book experi\xad
ence, Holdaway distinguished three phases of experience when
reading a bedtime story. The first phase is introduction to
the book for the purpose of enjoyment. During it the child
participates without pressure and may question to a small
degree. In the classroom setting, this phase offers opportu\xad
nity for children to predict what will happen in the story and
to recognize familiar vocabulary, but is primarily concerned
with enjoyment and pleasure."
"The second phase is referred to as the ”read-it-again"
one, during which the child asks to have the story read over
and over again. In the classroom, this repetition phase
offers an opportunity for increased participation in the
reading of the text and the enlarged print or the "big book"
becomes of increased importance. Children can see the text
and as the teacher points to each word as it is read,
specific aspects of print can be pointed out clearly. The
strategies of reading are presented to the children within a
meaningful context."
"In the third phase, the children spend time reading,
role-playing, and recreating the familiar experience with[¬e]"', 'Page 20:
[¬s]"their favorite books. Ideally, the children choose the books
they want to read and monitor themselves throughout the
process. Within the classroom setting, social interaction
provides opportunities for related activities in writing and
the arts.[¬e]"']

comp_anal_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Pearson product\x96moment correlations for the four dependent measures, scores for individual subjects on two vocabulary tests and two comprehension tests, were significant (\x01 \x03 .01, two- tailed). Because of the number of dependent variables and the degree of correlation among them, a multivariate analysis of vari- ance (MANOVA) was used to analyze effects of style and grade on vocabulary acquisition and comprehension (Hair, Anderson, Tatham, & Black, 1998). For the measure of vocabulary acquisi- tion, gains in the number of items correct from pretest to posttest were calculated for each subject. Means and standard deviations for vocabulary posttests are reported beside those for pretests in Table 1. Comprehension measures were based on the number of correct responses on the comprehension test for each book. Means and standard deviations for comprehension tests are listed in Table 2. Bartlett\x92s test of sphericity yielded statistically significant re- sults, approximate \x02 2 (9, N \x03 246) \x03 160.64, p \x03 .00, and evidence of intercorrelation among dependent variables that justi- fied MANOVA. Although numbers of subjects in Grade \x02 Style groups were not equal, Levene\x92s test supported an assumption of univariate homogeneity of variance for vocabulary acquisition, F(5, 240) \x03 .38 and 1.42, p \x03 .86 and .22, and comprehension scores, F(5, 240) \x03 1.89 and 2.15, p \x03 .01 and .06 (reported for Call Me Ahnighito and Everglades, respectively). Box\x92s M test, with a value of 54.11, indicated no significant differences, F(50, 102,218.20) \x03 1.04, p \x03 .40, and equality of variance\x96 covariance matrices across groups. These results and examinations of histo- grams and plots supported assumptions required by MANOVA, and an alpha level of .05 was set for all subsequent tests. Wilks\x92s lambda revealed statistically significant overall effects for grade, F(4, 237) \x03 17.64, p \x03 .00 (\x03 2 \x03 .23), and style, F(8, 474) \x03 9.93, p \x03 .00 (\x03 2 \x03 .14). Interactions between grade and style were not significant, F(8, 474) \x03 1.95, p \x03 .05 (\x03 2 \x03 .03).[¬e]"']

base_diff_ht: ['Page 65:\n[¬s]"The hypotheses that the differences between the comparison groups are equal to zero can be tested by using multivariate criteria, averaged univariate F- tests (a result of pooling all the individual contrasts), or polynomial contrasts. In order to use the averaged univariate F-tests, which are more powerful, especially for small sample sizes, Mauchly\'s test of sphericity was used to test the hypothesis that the covariance matrix of the transformed variables has a constant variance on the diagonal and zeroes off the diagonal. For each[¬e]"', 'Page 66:\n[¬s]"variable in this study, the observed significance level was > .05. Thus, the hypothesis of sphericity was not rejected, and the averaged univariate F-tests are reported. When the averaged univariate F-tests were significant for the group by time interaction, subsequent univariate F-tests were used to establish the phase or phases at which the differenco between the groups became significant and an effect size was then computed.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"1. The teacher read the book aloud to the group. She read the book again, inviting the children to join in when they could predict what comes next. The children took turns with choral reading of the book. The text was then read from a chart without the book’s picture cues. 2. The teacher and students read the story from the chart. Students were given sentence strips with lines from the story. They placed the sentence strips under the correspond\xad ing line on the chart. They were given individual word cards in order, which they placed under the match\xad ing words in the chart. 3. Students read the whole story[¬e]"', 'Page 4:\n[¬s]"chorally from the chart. The teacher placed individual word cards from sections of the story in random order at the bottom of the chart. Students matched the word cards to the words on the chart. When the dictated stories were used, the lessons were the same except for lesson one: 1. The teacher introduced the stim\xad ulus, e.g., a toy bus, and encouraged discussion. Students dictated a group language experience story. The teach\xad er read the story to the children and then they read it together.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"Session 1: The vocabulary word list of 12 words was presented to subjects with directions to read each word and, based on their own knowledge and prior experi-[¬e]"', 'Page 2:\n[¬s]"ence, to select one definition from among four choices supplied. After completing the activity, subjects were given the locations of the words in the text and were di\xad rected to read the sentence (s) in which a word was presented. They then analyzed the adequacy of their original choice of definition by comparing it to the meaning of the word derived from its contex\xad tual setting. This stage of instruc\xad tion had two purposes: (1) It mod\xad eled the process of deriving mean\xad ing from an analysis of the context in which a word is found. (2) It “sensitized" subjects to the terms in the textual context in which they would later be read. Session 2: Activities were pre\xad sented to provide practice using concept vocabulary and to rein\xad force meaning. The two activities were: (a) A word puzzle in which subjects read a definition and pro\xad vided the appropriate term, using letter clues and blanks represent\xad ing the number of letters in the word, (b) A vocabulary reinforce\xad ment activity in which subjects covered words as their definitions were read by the teacher and “called back" the words and defi\xad nitions when a row was completed.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"This study was designed to in\xad vestigate the effect of preteaching words representing important con\xad cepts on the acquisition and reten\xad tion of a unit of social studies con\xad tent. The preteaching of content vocabulary’ is based on the princi\xad ple that the advance introduction of terms representing key concepts will provide "cognitive anchors” around which the content can be organized[¬e]"']

['Page 3:
[¬s]"Thirty seven texts, varying in length between 200 and 400 words, were selected or written specifically for training students.[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"- Children read the text. - If there was some word they did not know, it was explained or - if possible - a strate\xad gy for discovering its meaning from cues given by the text was suggested. - Children were asked what was the most important information the author had tried to convey. - Following the answer, the child was asked why other aspects of the text could not be the main idea. No feedback was given during this dialogue."
"- Next, the teacher modelled - thinking aloud and writing on the blackboard - the think\xad ing process that he was following to represent graphically the hierarchical relations among text sentences, using syntactic and semantic cues given by the text. The identi \xad fication of main idea using the graphic representation was also modelled."
"- Teacher’s modelling was then discussed: What have I done? Why? What is the main idea according to what I have done? Is it the same idea as you first thought of? What process have I followed for summarizing the text?[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"- Once this process was finished, the teacher made explicit the criteria for recognizing what kind of structure the text had, what the main idea was, and how to summarize the text with the purpose of favouring learning. - Finally, children had to practice, under the supervision of the teacher, the process just learned. During this phase, children were sometimes given graphical diagrams, which they had to fill in with text ideas. "
"Subjects were given the standardized tests MI and Automen before instruction. After instruction, the MID test was given. Subjects were also interviewed after reading each of two texts. Before reading each text, subjects had to answer questions about reading purpose.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"strategies for identifying important information[¬e]"', 'Page 9:\n[¬s]" instruction in main idea comprehension[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]" teachers taught their students the strategies they had learne[¬e]"', 'Page 9:\n[¬s]"Procedure. In this study, teachers, after having received the training (teachers’ training results can be seen in Alonso-Tapia & Carrie do, in press), were told by the instruct or that they should apply the strategies learned in the context of their real classes over a period of three months. Thus, the purpose is that teachers genera lize the strategies and the method lea rned and adapt them to their students’ features, using curricular textbooks (without modification) in the context of their content area, in other words, teachers should incorporate into their curricular classes the knowledge acquired about strategies related to main idea comprehension. That is, every time they work in their classes with a text, they should apply the comprehension strate\xad gies according to the guidelines provided during the instruction period. In accordance with the training received, the strategies that teachers had to apply in their classroom were: previous knowledge activation about the content of the text, text structure strategy knowledge, hierar\xad chical representation of text ideas and text composition. To teach these strategies the teacher should model, explain and promote both guided and independent practice.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"Briefly, our expectations were that students of the experimental group would obtain high\xad er scores than those of the control group in the following variables: Top-level information recall (most important information), metacognitive aspects related to the process of main idea identification (knowledge of reading purpose and knowledge related to comprehension moni\xad toring), hierarchical representation of text ideas (semantic representation), referential repre\xad sentation of text ideas (situational representation), topic identification and metacognitive aspects related to this process (knowledge of features defining text topic), main idea identifi\xad cation and metacognitive aspects related to this process (knowledge of features defining main idea) and text structure knowledge.[¬e]"']
int_objec_info: increase students' understanding on subject, learn a strategy to learn
int_training_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]" 11 in-service teachers were taught how to teach the same strategies for identifying important information taught in the Study 1."\n"We have developed a two part training program addressed to teachers (see Carriedo & Alonso-Tapia, 1994; Alonso-Tapia & Carriedo, in press). The first part is a 30 hour course for training te achers in how to teac h reading comprehension strategies in the classroom (mainly those related to text structure). In this part, teachers learned the theo\xad retical concepts and strategies, and gained some experience in designing their classes accord\xad ing to these. The second part included fifteen practice sessions with the trainer, two hours every fortnight, over three months. The content of the program is described in Table 3.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 44:
[¬s]"The independent variable i n thi s study consisted of two
treatments: using LEA without basal readers present, or
using basal readers without LEA present. A classroom
observation checklist (see Appendix A) was developed to
ensure both treatments were present, either i n the
experimental group or i n the control group. This checklist
was largely composed of the criteri a used to define the
presence of LEA or the presence of basal readers."
"The specifi c criteri a on the checklist, used to define
LEA for thi s experiment, were the following, liste d i n Table
III: (a) speaking opportunities are present, (b) listenin g
opportunities are present, (c) students' interests initiat e
lessons, (d) meaningful experiences or high interest[¬e]"', 'Page 45:
[¬s]"activitie s initiat e writing and reading, (e) students
initiat e oral discussion, (f) seatwork i s based on student
initiate d oral discussion, (g) vocabulary comes from
students, (h) students' own stories are used as worksheets,
(i) students read thei r own written work, (j) students read
their peers' written work, and (k) i n creative writing,
students reproduce their own thoughts.[¬e]"', 'Page 49:
[¬s]"The specifi c criteri a on the checklist, used to define
the presence of basal readers for thi s experiment, were the
following, liste d i n Table IV: (a) students read from basal
readers, (b) students' seatwork i s based on basal readers,
(c) teacher-made or publisher worksheets are used, (d)
vocabulary comes from the teacher or from the basal reader,
and (e) creative writing activitie s are heavily structured by
the teacher.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 20:
[¬s]"LEA i s the name of a specifi c pedagogical scheme for
introducing reading and writing to beginning readers.[¬e]"', 'Page 21:
[¬s]"LEA involves children's own expressions and stresses the
interrelationship between listening, speaking, reading, and
writing (Hudelson, 1984; Kirkland, 1980; O'Donnell, 1968;
Thorn & Braun, 1974; Wiesendanger & Birlem, 1979). Simply
put, Veatch (1973) feels most educators would describe LEA as
an approach that involves the use of children's own language."
"Lee and Allen (1963) are more specific . They state LEA
reguires certain central beliefs, liste d here sequentially:
What the student thinks about he can talk about.
What he can talk about can be expressed i n painting,
writing, or some other form.
Anything he writes can be read.
He can read what he writes and what other people write.
As he represents the sounds he makes through speech with
symbols, he uses the same symbols (letters) over and
over.
What he has to say and write i s as important to him as
what other people have written for him to read.
Host of the words he uses are the same ones which are
used by other people who write for him to read.
(pp. 5-8)"
"Thorn and Braun (1974) fee l a successful LEA program
must include several important elements. Content and[¬e]"', 'Page 22:
[¬s]"methodology of the program must be determined by a knowledge
of chil d development. The program must emphasize, "language
as a tool of thinking and promote the development of each
chil d as an independent thinker" (Thorn & Braun, 1974,
p.354). It must be concerned with tota l language.
Success
i n reading and writing wil l depend upon the student's oral
language ability .
the catalyst for reading and writing.
It must use children's own experiences as
It should also provide
opportunities for expanding those experiences and creating
new ones i n order to further enlarge the student's language.[¬e]"', 'Page 46:
[¬s]"Children are be able to hear thei r teacher and
thei r peers talk about subjects and themes that are of real
interest to them (Feeley, 1983)."
"The more oral discussion present i n a classroom, the
more likel y speaking and listenin g skill s are developing.
As
Thorn and Braun (1974) suggest, reading and writing skill s
are intertwined with speaking and listenin g skills . Improved
speaking and listenin g skill s should result i n improved
reading and writing skills .[¬e]"', 'Page 47:
[¬s]"The vocabulary used during these discussions comes
chiefl y from the students. Classroom discussions,
Ashton-Warner (1963) feels, are more dynamic when the
students use the vocabulary and language that i s thei r own,
that they bring with them, into school.[¬e]"']

int_training_ht:
['Page 43:
[¬s]"The teacher of the experimental group was provided with
much greater direction. Although she was a strong proponent
of LEA and had used some LEA techniques for a number of
years, she was not totall y aware of what LEA meant and what
i t involved. During the course of the pilo t study and again,
at the beginning of thi s experiment, the researcher had
ongoing consultation with thi s teacher."
"Clarificatio n of what was meant by LEA and refinement of
LEA techinques formed the bulk of the teacher training.
Textbooks and manuals on LEA were provided and discussed.
Definitions and methodology were agreed upon. LEA
instruction was monitored and feedback was provided by the
researcher."
"On several occasions during the beginning of the
experiment, the researcher provided LEA lessons to the
students i n the classroom. These lessons consisted mostly of
writing down the students' stories verbatim, as described by
Moffett and Wagner (1976) and ensuring the students read
thei r own stories and shared them with their classmates.
These stories were then used i n extension activitie s
involving grammar and decoding skills .
When i t was clear that the teacher of the experimental
group was on track with LEA, she was lef t on her own.[¬e]"']
int_part_ht:
['Page 16:
[¬s]"The purpose of thi s study i s to test the value of LEA as
a means of introducing reading and writing to beginning L i
and L2 readers."
"Five questions were asked i n thi s experiment:
"Will there be significan t differences i n reading abilit y
between Grade One, LI and L2 students on a LEA program and
thei r peers on a program using a basal reading series?".
"Will there be significan t differences i n creative writing •
abilit y between the students i n the two programs?"
"Will there be significan t differences i n reading interest
between the LI and L2 students i n the LEA program and those
using the basal reading series?"
"Will the L2 students on the LEA program acquire
significantl y more English than their L2 peers on the basal
reading program?"
"Will these significan t differences exist i n reading ability ,
writing ability , and reading interest between the L2 subjects
i n the LEA program and the L2 subjects using the basal
reading series?"[¬e]"']
int_part_info: All key research questions are student-oriented

[¬s]"A classroom observation checklist was used to confirm
the presence of the two treatments: using LEA and not using
LEA.
The researcher took thi s checklist into classrooms, and
used i t to determine how much of the treatments were present
during the Language Arts lessons."
"In November, January, and February, the researcher
formally, but unobtrusively, observed each of the three[¬e]"', 'Page 61:
[¬s]"classrooms. These months were chosen for the observation
period because these are prime teaching months. By November,
the students and teachers had settled into their routines and
the Language Arts programs were definitel y underway. While
December was fille d with the disruptions of the Christmas
season, January and February were quiet, productive months of
the school year."
"Each classroom was observed on twelve different
occasions.
The observations occurred during various parts of
the Language Arts lessons. The researcher was able to
observe the beginning, middle, and end of lessons. In thi s
manner, i t was possible to obtain a survey of what was
happening i n the classrooms during the entire Language Arts
lesson.
Each observation lasted for approximately fiftee n
minutes. While sittin g at the back of the classroom, the
researcher marked off each item on the checklist as i t was
observed during the lesson.
After each classroom had been observed twelve times, the
checklists were compiled and file d unti l the treatment had
finished.[¬e]"']

[¬s]"SWELL attempts to develop these critical prerequisite literacy concepts, as a whole class program during the first three to six months of kindergarten through the Emergent Literacy program."
"Stage 1\x97Emergent Literacy 1. Story-telling and Retelling (STaR)."
"2. Conceptsabout Print (Clay, 1989) are taught systematically through Big Book activities and generalised in the story-retelling STaR component."
"3. The connections between speech and written activities are systematically taught in context at the end of the STaR story-retelling activities using words and sentences derived from both Big Books and the story books that are read in STaR. 4. Early phonological awareness concepts, such as recognition and production of rhyme and alliteration, are systematically introduced in context through Big Book activities and generalised in the story-retelling STaR component.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"5. Expressive and Receptive Language Development. The Peabody Language Devel- opment Program (Dunn, Smith, & Dunn, 1981) or CLAS Program (Plourde, 1995) is also added to the regular classroom program to provide additional models for language use and expression as well as development of specific vocabulary skills. 6. Emergent writing is a regularly programmed activity accepting drawings, scrib- ble, non-phonetic letter strips, invented and conventional spelling as valid communi- cation.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"In the dialogic reading program, each child was provided with a total of 8 books. Hints for prompt questions and recall prompts were added in each book. One book and the pictures[¬e]"', 'Page 9:\n[¬s]"for the corresponding book were distributed each week by teachers. Parents were encouraged to read each book twice in a week for 15 minutes each time with their children. The first book, a dialogic reading guideline, a calendar checklist, and pictures for that book were initially given to the parents. The parents were trained individually through a 20-minute training session by phone before the reading intervention started. They were trained to use special strategies and the materials given to encourage their children to be active storytellers in parent-child reading. The fundamental reading technique in dialogic reading is the PEER sequence in parent-child reading. The parent prompts the child to say something about the storybook, evaluates the child\x92s response, expands the child\x92s responses by rephrasing and adding information, and repeats the prompt to ensure the child has learned from the expansion.[¬e]"']

base_diff_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"The flow of participants through the study is summarized in
Figure S1 in the Supplemental Material available online. To
identify children with specific reading-comprehension diffi-
culties, we conducted screenings in Year 4 classrooms (8- to
9-year-old children) in 23 schools in Yorkshire, England. The
socioeconomic backgrounds of the schools varied from very
low to high (as assessed by parental income, parental educa-
tional level, and percentage of children eligible for free school
meals). All of the children were taught in mainstream class-
rooms following the English national curriculum. At screen-
ing, group-administered measures of spelling (an adapted
version of Wechsler Objective Reading Dimensions, WORD;
Wechsler, 1993), nonverbal IQ (Raven’s Standard Progressive
Matrices; Raven, 1998), and listening comprehension (adapted
from the Neale Analysis of Reading Ability: Second Revised
British Edition, NARA II, Form A; Neale, 1997) were given to
whole classes of children. In each school, children who
achieved the lowest listening-comprehension scores relative
to their peers were identified. Of these children, only those
with age-appropriate spelling and nonverbal ability (standard
scores > 80) were selected to complete individually adminis-
tered tests of reading comprehension and reading accuracy
(NARA II, Form B; Neale, 1997) and the Test of Word Read-
ing Efficiency (TOWRE; Torgesen, Wagner, & Rashotte,
1999).[¬e]"']

comp_anal_ht:
['Page 9:
[¬s]"For purposes of these analyses, we looked at student data from two of the three in-
tervention groups, the group that received the storybook intervention (n = 34) and the
control group (n = 30) that received a sounds and letters module of a commercial read-
ing program (Open Court; Adams et al., 2000). We chose to focus our analyses on
these two groups to provide a clearer comparison between students who received the
storybook intervention and students in the control group.[¬e]"']
comp_var_ht: NA
clust_anal_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]"To test models of differential effectiveness based on students’ initial receptive vocabu-
lary, we compared the regressions of vocabulary posttest measures (taught and untaught)
on pretest levels of the same variables and the pretest level ofPPVT. Because we were in-
terested in comparing vocabulary growth both across groups (i.e., the storybook group
compared with the control group) and within groups (i.e., taught vocabulary compared
with untaught vocabulary within the storybook group), we used structural equation mod-
eling (SEM) to estimate a bivariate outcome regression model. The fact that the taught
and untaught outcomes were substantially correlated and likely to remain so even after
controlling for predictors precluded the use of simpler ordinary least squares regression
procedures.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"an 18-week program of direct and extended vocabulary instruction with kindergarten stu- dents not only on proximal measures of target word knowledge but also transfer measures of generalized language and literacy.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"we used a quasi-experimental design.[¬e]"', 'Page 9:
[¬s]"The intervention consisted of 36 half-hour instructional lessons (2 lessons per week over 18 weeks). We developed the intervention around 18 storybooks that were read aloud to students followed by interactive postreading activities. The story-reading portion of the intervention averaged 10 to 20 min per session, and the postreading activities averaged 10 to 15 min. Each storybook was read twice during a week. The identical intervention was implemented in Schools A, B, and C. We selected storybooks that would be of high interest to kindergarten students and that included engaging narratives, rich language, and illustrative pictures. Priority was given to storybooks that depicted multicultural characters and themes. We selected three target vocabulary words from each storybook to teach directly (54 total). Our goal was to identify target words that were unfamiliar to students but whose meanings they would be able to understand.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]" investigating the ef\x1ecacy of an 18-week program of direct and extended vocabulary instruction with kindergarten stu- dents not only on proximal measures of target word knowledge but also transfer measures of generalized language and literacy.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 11:\n[¬s]"Prior to the start of the study, interventionists (i.e., kindergarten classroom teachers at Schools A and B, and graduate student interventionists at School C) participated in a 1-day training. During the training, members of the research team modeled vocabulary lesson activities and provided interventionists with opportunities for supervised practice with immediate corrective feedback.[¬e]"']
int_leng_info: Each session lasted approximately 30 minutes.   The story-reading portion of the intervention averaged 10-20 minutes and the postreading activities, 10-15 minutes.

Phase One of the alternative instructional unit modeled for students how to select important words relevant to a selection and how to learn those words at a fairly deep level. As they read it, they were to underline each important word as they en- countered it, and to predict the word's meaning from the context of the story. They were also in- structed to look up the word in the dictionary and to select the definition appropriate to the context and then to bring that definition to class the next day. The following day, Chris integrated his vocabulary instruction into the discussion of the reading selec- tion. Students read each word aloud in context along with its definition. Then the word was dis- cussed as it directly tied into the plot, theme, and characters of the s"
"f the important words for that reading. Phase Two of the alternative instructional unit was designed to gradually release responsibility for the vocabulary activities so that students could se- lect and learn important words on their own (Pearson & Gallagher, 1983). Beginning about the fifth week, Chris placed students in small groups and assigned the groups to find their own im"
"omprehension of the story. This initial phase of gradual release of responsi- bility from teacher to students took about 2 week"
" Phase Three, students developed indepen- dence in using their new strategies for selecting im- portant words. Beginning on the ninth week of in- struction, they worked alone without Chris's guidance or peer support to select important words for the novel larzan of the Apes. Thus, Chris released complete responsibility to each individual student for selecting words and defending the[¬e]"']

could not recall seeing before. Acquainted words
were those that students recognized but could not
necessarily define. Established words were those
that students immediately recognized and could
readily defin"

characters, themes, plots, or settings of a selection.
While 66% of the students cited that they chose the
words because they did not know what they meant,
students also cited the following reasons: (a) the
words described characters (20%), (b) the words de-
scribed the plot or story action (16%), (c) the book
"picked them," (9%), and (d) the words described
something (7%). Thus, some students had a sense[¬e]"']

completion of their high school education.
Both English classes used for this study were
taught by Chris. Both classes consisted of students
who chose to take the course called Action and
Adventure. This class, like all other English cours-
es in the school, was an elective. Students were not
grouped by ability. However, because of the homo-
geneous population of the school, it is reasonable
to assume that students in these two classes also
formed a homogeneous group in terms of ability
as well as interest in the course. All students en-
rolled in both classes participated in the study, as it
was considered part of the instructional program

int_desc_ht:
['Page 110:
[¬s]"The session began with a short discussion of thinking silently as opposed to thinking aloud, things that are confusing as one reads, and what a reader can do to fix-up the confusions. The following directions adapted from those used by Bereiter and Bird (1985, p . 145), were typed and given to the subjects to read silently as the researcher read them orally: 1. I will be showing you some ways to read that will help you better understand what you read. I will read some passages out loud, saying my thoughts out loud as I go along. I will say what is confusing for me while I read and what I can do to fix it up. You will follow on your copy. Pay attention to the types of things I think and say while I'm reading. 2. You will then be given a passage to read. You will read it orally with a partner and apply the same think aloud strategy I used when I read for you. As you read, stop frequently and tell your partner when something is confusing and then tell your partner what you will do to fix it up. Wherever you see a red dot on the paper, I want you to stop and tell what you're thinking. You can stopother places, too, but always stop where there's a red dot. 3. After you have finished the reading, fill in the signposts check sheet. 4. You and your partner will tape record each other. These directions were also reviewed at the beginning of the second and third sessions with minor changes given in directions 2 and 3 - namely "read it silently" and, "tell me everything you can remember about what you read" and "answer[¬e]"', 'Page 111:
[¬s]"some written question" after haviii3 read the passage.[¬e]"', 'Page 112:
[¬s]"I. PASSIVE COGNITIVE MODELING GROUP Step 1 Cognitive Modeling: The researcher cognitively- modeled a passage for the subjects. This modeling followed the same think-aloud strategy used in session 1 with the same emphasis on problem identification and fix-up strategies. The think-aloud steps and fix-up strategies remained posted throughout the study. Step 2 Verbal Protocol: Next, following a procedure developed by Meichenbaum and Goodman (1971), each subject individually performed the modeled think-aloud strategy to him/herself while silently reading another passage with no help from the researcher. Following the think-aloud the subject received a list of the think-aloud steps and was asked to self-check this "signpost" listing to see if he/she performed the steps in the strategy. Step 3 Comprehension Assessment: Immediately following, the subject was asked to work on a personal interests questionnaire which served as a buffer task. Based on Kintsch's (1974) work on memory, the insertion of an "unrelated buffer passage" between reading and recalling helps to block short term memory and helps assure that propositional memory and not short term memory is being tested. The use of a questionnaire for this purpose has been used in other studies (Mandel and 96[¬e]"', 'Page 113:
[¬s]"Johnson, 1984; Pritchard, 1987) and was therefore used in this study. (See Appendix P.) After several minutes, the subject was instructed to orally retell the passage that he/she just read with the instruction Tell me everything you can remember about the passage you just read. What you might want to do is pretend that I haven't read it and that you're going to tell me everything you can remember about it. After the subject completed the retelling, probes were used"
" (e.g. Student: "Well, it was about manatees and where they lived, and what they eat, and how they eat." Probe: "Are there any other things it told about the manatees?" Student: "Ya, they eat under water, and they live near Florida in lagoons and stuff like that." Probe: "Is there anything else y o u ’d like to add?" Student: "No.") After completing the probed retelling, the subject was instructed on how to complete the sentence verification assessment and allowed time to do so. (See Appendix K . )[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]" a comprehension procedure that makes visible to students their prior knowledge about a topic and the structures in expository text. The procedure used reciprocal-like teaching formats for the design of group interactions during instruction, as well as semantic mapping to make text struc\xad tures apparent to students."
"Reciprocal teaching refers to the process whereby students take turns assuming the re\xad sponsibilities of the teacher for leading discussion about short sections of the text by using four reading strategies: questioning, summarizing, clarifying, and predicting text information[¬e]"', 'Page 2:
[¬s]" In POSSE, students employ a variety of reading strategies, such as Predicting ideas based upon background knowledge, Organizing predicted textual ideas and background knowledge based upon text structure, Searching/Summarizing by searching for the text structure in the expository passage and summarizing the main ideas, and Evaluating their comprehension.[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"POSSE students take turns leading the comprehension dialogue by asking questions, summarizing, and clarifying.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"In summary, POSSE contained spe\xad cific elements that structured the read\xad ing dialogue. These included (a) view\xad ing knowledge as socially constructed activity; (b) focusing on social inter\xad actions within a cognitive appren\xad ticeship model to promote learning; (c) emphasizing dialogue about literacy content and process; and (d) promot\xad ing assisted teaching by scaffolding (e.g., bridging the gap between known and unknown; prompting or guiding students to independent performance levels; mapping the content in exposi\xad tory text; using think sheets and cue cards to promote self-regulation as the learning goal).[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 17:\n[¬s]"This study sought to explore the ef\xad fects of an instructional program on the comprehension abilities of students with mild disabilities. The experimen\xad tal intervention that was examined in this study, POSSE, was designed to enhance students\' knowledge about the reading process and the role of text-structure knowledge. However, it was not just a procedure for teaching expository comprehension. POSSE in\xad volved the construction of an entire teaching-learning context and a lesson dialogue in which (a) reading strategies were made visible; (b) teachers and students talked about comprehension strategies and problems; and (c) self\xad talk was made apparent through the procedural facilitation format of the think-sheets, teacher think-alouds, and the reciprocal-teaching format. The question addressed in this study was whether such an integrated approach to instruction would be effective with students with mild disabilities, par\xad ticularly, students with learning dis\xad abilities—a population for whom many authors recommend the teaching of a few strategies sequentially and thor\xad oughly, rather than presenting them simultaneously (see Swanson, 1989).[¬e]"', 'Page 5:\n[¬s]"The purpose of the present study was to compare the effectiveness of the POSSE instructional program, which was designed to incorporate the three instructional principles, with another instructional program in which those principles were not prominent.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"During training, prospective teach\xad ers attended two 3-hour meetings held with two different researchers, who presented them the rationale for the program, as well as information about the procedures, benefits, and effects. The teachers then watched videotapes of other teachers using the program, and implemented the procedures with peers as the researchers gave them feedback. After this training period, the teachers implemented the pro\xad gram, in classrooms, with children. They were closely supervised and monitored by their university practi- cum supervisors, who observed on a biweekly basis. Feedback was pro\xad vided to interns on the basis of their teaching performance. Interns also audiotaped their lessons and con\xad ducted self-analyses of their teaching performance based on the patterns of interactions between teachers and students desired for the K-W-L and POSSE treatments.[¬e]"']
int_dur_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"The study began in the fall and lasted for 8 weeks. Two of those weeks were devoted to pretesting, the initial train\xad ing of teachers, and posttesting. Thus, the instructional intervention occurred over 6 weeks,[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"with 4 days of instruc\xad tion per week[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"A COMPARISON OF THE EFFECTS OF TWO DIFFERENT LEVELS OF IMPLEMENTATION OF READ-ALOUDS ON KINDERGARTEN STUDENTS’ COMPREHENSION AND VOCABULARY ACQUISITION[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 12:
[¬s]"Nearly all recommendations for improving the quality of preschool and kindergarten experience include reading aloud to children.[¬e]"', 'Page 86:
[¬s]" In the full model intervention, teachers were trained to use scripted approaches to reading aloud using five research-based (Brabham & Lynch-Brown, 2002; Reese & Cox, 1999) components of reading: (a) an introduction to the book that orients children to the story’s major problem; (b) teacher comments that model the process of making inferences from pivotal story events; (c) “rich” explanations of five to nine target vocabulary words; (d) after-reading open-ended questions designed to assist children with the explanation of several pivotal story events; and (e) guided (scaffolded) reconstruction of the story.[¬e]"', 'Page 87:
[¬s]"The"
"group of teachers in each school served as the control. These teachers read aloud the same books as those teachers employing either of the two intervention models, but read the book as they would traditionally read to a class. No vocabulary emphasis, open-ended questions, or guided reconstructions were scripted for control group teachers; but less scaffolded retellings (similar to those in the parsimonious model) were assigned for the third day of each week.[¬e]"', 'Page 98:
[¬s]"Teachers who employed the full model intervention were supplied with book introductions that oriented students to each story’s major problem.[¬e]"', 'Page 99:
[¬s]"Control group teachers were not provided scripted protocols to which to adhere because they followed their typical or traditional pattern of reading aloud; instead, they were given brief guidelines about reading the story (answer children’s questions, entertain their comments, but do not add to the conversation).[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 12:
[¬s]"The classroom protocol must be adhered to, but it was up to schools how often they conducted P4C lessons."
"With guidance from the teacher, the dialogue is focused not only on the chosen questions but also on the assumptions that lie behind the answers and the criteria used to make judgements."
"The following are the main ten stages of a P4C session: 1. Getting set 2. Presentation of stimulus 3. Thinking time 4. Question making 5. Question airing 6. Question choosing 7. First thoughts 8. Building 9. Last thoughts 10. Review[¬e]"', 'Page 14:
[¬s]"P4C, as promoted by SAPERE, is a template to practise and organise a classroom session for philosophical enquiry. The intervention suggests useful stages of initiating, practising, and concluding the dialogue with pupils. However, it does not have any specified materials or stimuli that must be used; there are only examples and suggestions. The tens step outlined above are a guide to organising the classroom dialogue and can be used flexibly as the teacher\x92s expertise grows. [¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]"determine the effect of the P4C programme on the Key Stage 2 scores of pupils who were in Year 5 when the schools were randomised and Year 6 by the end of the trial. A further outcome was the scores on the CAT4 (Cognitive Ability Test, Fourth Edition; GL Assessment website) for those in Years 4 and 5 at the start and in Years 5 and 6 when post- tested. A subsequent aim proposed by the developers and agreed by the funders was to consider the short-term impact of P4C on pupils\x92 experiences at school, and their relationship with teachers and peers.[¬e]"']
int_prov_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]" Society for the Advancement of Philosophical Enquiry and Reflection in Education (SAPERE)[¬e]"']
int_training_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]"Schools that undertook P4C received two types of training: introductory training for all staff in year 1 and additional days of in-school support as well as access to resources. All the training and support was provided by SAPERE-accredited trainers using standardised SAPERE methods.[¬e]"', 'Page 12:
[¬s]"All staff received two days of training (SAPERE Level 1). Some schools were able to devote two whole days to the training, while others decided to have one day plus an additional day of classroom demonstrations by the trainer together with two after-school sessions. "
"In addition to the introductory training, schools were offered additional support. The first step was for trainers to demonstrate P4C with children in each school. In subsequent sessions, the trainers supported teachers doing P4C by helping them plan lessons and giving them feedback. They also advised teachers who had taken on a leading role for P4C in the school. Nine support days were available to schools over the two years of the project.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"Teachers were trained in P4C by the Society for the Advancement of Philosophical Enquiry and Reflection in Education (SAPERE).[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]" The work sheets contained selected examples of the aid un der discussion, puzzles, check tests, short selec tions reprinted from newspapers, and several short selections prepared by the writer. The ma jority of the exercises were based"\n"rom a fifth-grade social studies text. The experimental lessons were taught in thirty five minute periods three times per week for a period of four weeks. An attempt was made through the teaching of these lessons to help pupils build meaning for a word by studying and understanding the sur rounding context, i.e., by visualizing the descrip tions or meanings suggested in a sentence in order to set up the context and to see the relationships of descriptions and meanings in order to construct the meaning of the previously unknown word. Rather than encourage the children to do partial sounding and to use the various skills to get the pronunciation, the children were urged to con centrate on the meaning, with the idea in mind that if one could figure out the meaning, it might be worthwhile to learn to pronounce the word. This was particularly urged in the instances where artificial (nonsense) words were used. The children were taught to pursue the meaning of the word. They were encouraged to disregard dif ficult pronunciation problems or non-recognition of meaning once the pronunciation was figured out and to concent[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"Thinking, Doing, Talking Science (TDTS) comprises a series of professional development sessions, support, and resources for primary school teachers. It aims to improve pupils\x92 thinking skills and science attainment by making science lessons more conceptually challenging, more practical, and more interactiv"\n"two teachers from each school participated in five days of professional development (both were Year 5 teachers or, in one-form entry schools, Year 5 and another member of staff such as the science subject leader). Due to staff changes, in many cases these were not the same teachers that had taken part in the pilot. In the professional development sessions, the teachers were shown how to plan and deliver their own conceptually challenging lessons, tailored to the needs and abilities of their pupils. They also spent two days in-school planning and sharing knowledge to ensure the strategies were embedded.[¬e]"']
