int_desc_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]" These techniques include questioning and giving feedback. They are: (a) ask ªwhº questions (i.e., what, where, when, why, who, which, and how questions); (b) follow correct answers with another question; (c) repeat what the child says; (d) help the child as needed; (e) praise and encourage; and (f) shadow the child\'s interest. The techniques in the second part require that the adult ask open-ended questions and expand the child\'s comments. In both parts, the importance of having fun during shared reading is emphasized[¬e]"', 'Page 8:\n[¬s]"The intervention took place over a four-week period (i.e., 20 weekdays). All teachers were instructed to provide the children with a daily minimum of ten minutes of reading and to read each book provided twice. Each day-care center was provided with ®ve books for the ®rst two weeks, at which point the ®ve books were exchanged between centers for the following two weeks. Hence, the children in both centers were exposed to the same books. The three teachers in each center decided amongst themselves the order of presentation of the ®ve books in each of the two-week periods. The dialogic-reading teachers were instructed to read in a dialogic fashion and the regular-reading teachers were instructed to read in their customary fashion. Teachers were also told that the books provided by the experimenter need not be the only books read to the children during the course of the study. The parents who agreed to participate in the home intervention were asked to read to their child for a minimum of ten minutes and to read each book provided at least ®ve times during the week. The home-intervention parents at the dialogic- reading center were asked to read in a dialogic fashion and the home-intervention parents at the regular-reading center were asked to read in their customary fashion. The home-intervention parents were to receive fewer and different books than the teachers. Home-intervention parents were provided with a book each Monday afternoon and asked to return it the following Monday morning. Thus, home-intervention parents received a maximum of four books. Notes reminding home-intervention parents to return books were left in the children\'s lockers on Friday afternoons. Home-intervention parents had to return a book before they received another.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]" The authors tested whether the bene®cial effects of storybook reading would be greater when children were active participants as compared to children who participated in a regular shared book-reading situation.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"Dialogic Reading Training. Teachers at the dialogic-reading center received training in dialogic reading in a one-hour group session at the day-care during the week prior to the intervention. The sessions consisted of an introduction to dialogic reading and the presentation of a thirty-minute training video on dialogic reading, as well as role-playing and discussions. The training video was produced by Whitehurst, Arnold, and Lonigan (1990) and was successfully used to train parents in using dialogic reading (Arnold et al., 1994). During the presentation of the video, the experimenter stopped the video periodically for role-playing and discussion. Teachers were provided with a handout summarizing the techniques of dialogic reading.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:\n[¬s]"The training of parents at the dialogic-reading center was conducted at the day-care center and was identical to that received by teachers. int_desc_ht: ['Page 48:\n[¬s]"After the initial testing was completed, the children receiving the treatment initially received 10 storybooks on tape, which were geared for their age and interest level. Titles included some of the best-selling children’s picture books, nursery rhymes, classic fairy tales, and books that combine narrative and song[¬e]"', 'Page 49:\n[¬s]"(Appendix F). In addition, these children were given an easy to operate tape recorder specified by the manufacturer (Fisher Price) for independent use by children age three years and up. Four size-C batteries for the tape recorder’s immediate operation were distributed, along with two other sets of four batteries that were to be used as a back up. The tape recorder and recorded stories were the children’s to keep. Every 7 to 10 days, the children were given another set of approximately 10 stories on tape to be listened to, in addition to the ones previously given. The audiotapes were distributed to their respective preschools in large, individual manila envelopes that had the child’s name clearly written on the outside. The children from home school families received their additional audiobooks by postal mailings that were sent at similar intervals. Written reinforcement (Appendix E) was issued to the parents of the treatment group to encourage them to make the taped stories available for their children’s use. Lists of suggested times the youngsters might listen to the tapes were included. Random telephone calls to the parents of children in the treatment group was executed to further encourage the audiobooks be made available to these children.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 23:\n[¬s]"The purpose of this study was to determine if as an alternative or in addition to parents reading aloud, children could increase their vocabulary by frequently listening to audio recorded storybooks that are absent the visual images of illustrations or text. Any such improvement in vocabulary acquisition could be significant in light of vocabulary’s major role in literary development.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 36:\n[¬s]"The teachers were instructed to have the children sit on the rug in a group in front of the teacher who was seated on a rocking chair. This was established as the standard procedure and setting for the aural cloze instruction. The teachers were to hold the storybooks so that the children could see the pictures and the text as the teacher orally read the text to the children. A procedure whereby the teacher stopped reading and looked at the children as the signal for the chil\xad dren to supply the deleted word was established."\n"Each word supplied by the children was to be discussed and its relationship to the context explored. The children were to be encour\xad aged to supply many different words which could complete the passage and still "make sense."[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 11:\n[¬s]"The purpose of the present study was to determine the effectiveness of aural cloze as an instructional technique in improving kindergarten children\'s vocabulary and listening comprehension through the development of their ability to supply words deleted from orally presented materials.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 36:\n[¬s]"The subjects in this study were taught by two kindergarten teachers. The two kindergarten teachers received a one-hour session in the use of aural cloze instruction as a teaching technique prior to the start of the project."\n"Specifically, training centered on using one word replacement, discussion of different words which could complete meaning, and the use of picture and/or context clues. Additional meetings were held weekly during the aural cloze in\xad struction training to discuss progress and recomnendations for adjust\xad rents.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 38:
[¬s]"TA procedures. In the first TA lesson, the RAs introduced the purpose of the study while reading The Magic School Bus in the Solar System (Cole, 1992). The RAs pointed out that the characters in the story often thought aloud about what they were seeing and learning. The RAs told the participants that they would be learning to think aloud as they read. The RAs then read the story orally and modeled thinking aloud about[¬e]"', 'Page 39:
[¬s]"the content of the story. The RAs told the students that if they had difficulty, they would teach them some strategies to help them understand science passages better. The RAs explained that the four strategies help readers to think about what the information in science passages means. After the RAs finished modeling thinking aloud and strategy use, the participants practiced thinking aloud while reading sections of The Magic School Bus in the Solar System (Cole, 1992) with the RAs' guidance. This initial lesson concluded with students generating a set of questions related to space that they would like to learn in the lessons together. The students wrote these questions and drew pictures of objects found in space on black construction paper using colored pencils. Each subsequent TA lesson included pre-reading activities, silent reading with monitoring, oral reading with thinking aloud, and summarization to conclude the lesson. Prior to silent reading, the RAs read a scripted statement to inform the students that some of the passages contained mistakes made by the author, such as typographical errors, sentences that did not make sense, or contradictory information. The RAs then prompted the students to attend for errors in the text and to underline any places in the passage where they lost the meaning or believed there was a problem with the text. The RAs also told the students to underline sentences containing any unknown words. After silent reading was completed, the pairs of sixth graders took turns orally reading a sentence, thinking aloud about the meaning, and telling what they were doing to understand the text better. The RAs kept a written record of the sixth graders' miscues while reading orally. When the participants' think-aloud verbalizations indicated an inaccurate or incomplete understanding of the text, explicit instruction was initiated in one of the four strategic areas (see Table 24). These circumstances included students' (a)[¬e]"', 'Page 40:
[¬s]"miscues in oral reading without self-correction, (b) appeals for help, (c) verbalization of incorrect information or understanding of text, (c) failure to acknowledge or correct embedded errors in the text indicating a failure to monitor, or (e) other behaviors that indicated a lack of understanding of a word or section of text. Based on observations of students' reading behavior, the RAs selected a strategic activity (e.g., connecting) that would be beneficial and supported its use. Each time RAs initiated strategy instruction they briefly named the strategy and told its purpose (Baumann et al., 1993; Bereiter & Bird, 1985). Although strategy use was promoted throughout the oral reading and thinking- aloud phase, special attention was given to sections of text with embedded errors. If participants had not underlined an embedded error, or if think-aloud statements indicated a failure to understand the text, RAs prompted the readers to monitor and repair the error. The RAs also encouraged flexible use of strategies. For example, if a student only explained, the RAs challenged the student to try to connect as well. If a participant relied largely on personal connections that were only distantly related to the text (Cote & Goldman, 1999), the RAs encouraged them to try relevant text-to-text connections instead. The RAs' objective was to break into the rigidity of the participants' strategic behavior, supplementing useful strategies and supplanting less useful ones.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 15:\n[¬s]"Thinking aloud was selected and implemented as an intervention to guide and focus instructors\' intervention in science text comprehension and strategy use, and to promote students\' awareness of comprehension breakdowns and initiation of self- regulatory processes.[¬e]"']

Prior to the beginning of intervention lessons, each RA participated in five 3-hour group training sessions, and one individual training session with the researcher. Agenda and materials from training sessions are included in Appendix I. In[¬e]"', 'Page 46:\n[¬s]"In total, the RAs participated in 16 hours of training, 10 hours specifically related to TA procedures and 6 hours related to QR, general procedures such as record-keeping, and science passage content.[¬e]"']

int_name_info: Seminar to enlarge understanding of an idea
int_desc_ht:
['Page 59:
[¬s]"The seminar and the typical lesson conditions were to differ along the lines of the three distinguishing characteristics of the seminar outlined in Chapter II. That is, seminars were to be (a) group processes with the leader joining participants in a search for answers, (b) based on questions that cannot be answered "right or wrong," and (c)[¬e]"', 'Page 60:
[¬s]"centered on idea development. In contrast, lessons were to (a) follow a prescribed plan developed by the teacher, (b) concentrate on questions which do have right or wrong answers, and (c) have coverage of a topic as their goal.[¬e]"', 'Page 61:
[¬s]"The seminar observation group viewed a video of the seminar. In this way they were exposed to the same information as the SP group, but had neither the expectation of being called on to respond nor the experience of participating. SO groups viewed the video of the seminar conducted at the other school. This prevented observers' recognition of students in the video from having an unintended influence on results. The principal investigator, rather than the teacher/leader, met with the SO group and showed the video of the other school's seminar. Otherwise the procedure was the same. Because seminar videos had to be imported from the other school, the SO condition was conducted the week following the seminar and lesson in each school.[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: Seminar condition is a group process where questions have no right/wrong answers aimed to study how the idea of decalaration for independence developed.  Typical lesson condition was teacher lead where questions posed had right/wrong answers and the aim was to cover the topic area.  Video/seminar observation group saw a recorded vdeo of the first condition, taped in a different school.

int_training_ht: ['Page 60:\n[¬s]"The principal investigator provided teacher/leaders with a content analysis of the first four paragraphs of The Declaration (See Appendix A) and verbal instructions on the manner in which the two conditions were to be conducted. int_desc_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]"Year 5 teachers were asked to run 11 planning/review/refocusing cycles with their classes, six in phase 1 (‘Expanding repertoires’) and five in phase 2 (‘Advancing dialogue’)—meaning the entire intervention programme lasts for 20 weeks across two terms. During phase 1 (‘Expanding repertoires’), the focus was on increasing and enhancing the different kinds of talk used by teachers and pupils. During phase 2 (‘Advancing dialogue’) the focus was on applying the repertoires within a six-week programme in English, mathematics, science, and one non-core subject.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"The aim of the intervention was to raise levels of engagement and attainment across English, maths, and science in primary schools by improving the quality of teacher and pupil talk in the classroom[¬e]"', 'Page 7:\n[¬s]"The intervention aimed: • to maximise the quality and educational impact of classroom talk, building on prior work on dialogic teaching and on international evidence; • to encourage a classroom culture that engages pupils in the task in hand and retains their attention and interest; • to meet, but also go beyond, the requirements for spoken language in the national curriculum, giving particular attention to those kinds of talk through which pupils learn to reason, explain, justify, argue, speculate, evaluate, and in other ways think for themselves; • to advance this higher-order talk across the curriculum, but devote particular attention to it in the teaching of English, mathematics, and science; and • to raise pupils’ standards of attainment in literacy, numeracy, and science above the levels that teaching without such an intervention is likely to achieve.[¬e]"']

comp_anal_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"Although analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) is often used as a test statistic in experimental designs, the ANCOVA was not used in this work because the correla- tion between pretest and posttest scores for each of the dependent measures was less than .4 (see Myers, 1972). Specifically, the correlation between pretest and posttest elaborated and non-elaborated scores was .28 and .11, respectively, suggesting that a repeated-measures design would be more appropriate.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]" Because much of the program would be implemented at a distance from research staff, with little to no op- portunity for coaching or feedback, the directions and materials pro- vided to teachers were explicit; these included a set of all books to be read; a schedule for reading; and a description of the scope, se- quence, and frequency of print-related targets to be addressed during each read-aloud. Concerning the titles and reading schedule, teach- ers were provided a set of 30 commercially available children \x92 s texts in the fall of the year. The texts were carefully selected so that each contained a number of interesting print features such as font changes and character speech bubbles; the presence of such features in books is influential to how often preschool teachers will comment on print during read-alouds (Zucker, Justice, & Piasta, 2009). Teachers also"
"received a schedule specifying a specific title to be read during each week of the academic year (see Justice et al., 2009)."
"The reading schedule was identical for all teachers. Teachers were asked to read each week \x92 s scheduled book four times within a given week and to have no more than one read- aloud session within a day; however, the exact days of the week and the time of day at which the teacher conducted the read-alouds was left to the discretion of the teacher. Additionally, teachers were asked to conduct the read-aloud with the entire class in a whole-class session. At the end of a given week of reading, teachers were asked to place the completed book in the classroom library and to not read it again as a whole-class activity. Teachers were told that they could engage in any additional read-aloud activities that they liked, to include whole-class and small-group sessions, but that these should not include the study books."
"Concerning the scope, sequence, and frequency of print-related targets to be addressed during read-alouds, a set of 15 print knowl- edge targets (i.e., objectives) were linked to each book that was read over the 30 weeks. All teachers in the high-dose print-referencing condition were to follow this prescribed scope and sequence of in- struction for the entirety of the intervention. Specifically, each week, teachers would read a prescribed book and would address two print knowledge targets each time they read the book. Across weeks, the focus of instruction cycled across instructional targets to provide children with a balanced and varied exposure to the targets through- out the 30 weeks of the program."
"teachers were given gen- eral suggestions on how to use verbal (e.g., questioning about print) and nonverbal (e.g., tracking the print) references to make print a salient aspect of read-aloud sessions and to address the 15 targets. Teachers were asked to try to address each print target approximately two times in a read-aloud session.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"This study was conducted to determine the effectiveness of teachers \x92 use of a print-referencing style during whole-class read-alouds with respect to accelerating 4- and 5-year- old children \x92 s print-knowledge development.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"Some professional development activities and resources were provided to teachers to support their implementation of the interven- tion. First, teachers in the high-dose print-referencing group attended an 8-hr workshop before the academic school year in which they were given (a) information on children \x92 s print knowledge and emergent literacy development, (b) an overview of how to read with a print-referencing style and prior findings of its efficacy, and (c) hands-on practice incorporating references to print in read-aloud sessions with workshop partners. Second, teachers received two brief feedback letters (at weeks 8 and 22) detailing strengths and areas for improvement regarding their use of a print-referencing style. This feedback letter was tailored to each individual teacher and was de- veloped by research staff who had reviewed the designated week \x92 s videotaped book-reading session (submitted to the research team by the teacher for fidelity purposes). Third, teachers attended a 3-hr winter workshop (conducted by the research team midway through the program) to review general principles of print referencing.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 10:
[¬s]"Unlike subjects in Groups 1, 2, and 3, subjects in Groups 4 and 5 received training on the six difficult vocabulary words prior to passage reading. Training for both Groups 4 and 5 was conducted with only three of the six words at a time and consisted of the following sequence of procedures and instructions: 1. Experimenter presented one index card (containing one vocab\xad ulary word and meaning) to the subject. The card was placed on the desk in front of the subject. 2. Experimenter: “This word is altercations. What word is this?" 3. Child: “Altercations." 4. Experimenter: “Correct, altercations. What does altercations mean?” (The experimenter points to meaning given on card). 5. Child: ‘■Fights" 6. Experimenter: “Yes, altercations means fights. Listen, do you have altercations with your teacher? [Child responds.] Do you have altercations with a tree? [Child responds.] So, what does altercations mean?” 7. Child: “Fights."[¬e]"', 'Page 11:
[¬s]"The experimenter placed the first card to the side with the word facing up, within the subject’s view, and presented the second card. The experimenter followed Steps 2-7 when introducing the second word, e.g., antagonists. Following the training on the second word, the experimenter placed only the most recently introduced word face up and asked review questions. "
" If the child did not respond or responded with the incorrect meaning of a word, the experimenter immediately presented the appropriate card and prompted the subject to generate the correct meaning by pointing to the word and saying, “What does altercations mean? So, do you have altercations with your antagonists?'' The experimenter repeated Steps 2-7 for the third word and then asked review questions. Following this cumulative review of the three words, the experimenter then tested each word individually, giving feedback by showing the appropriate card. The same procedure was followed with the remaining three words {maligned, bailiff, incarcerated). All six words were then reviewed three times. Training criterion consisted of six consecutively correct responses for the three list presentations. "
" The only difference in training for subjects assigned to Group 5 involved integrating vocabulary training during passage reading. In the integration strategy, the experimenter stopped and prompted the subject to generate the meanings of the difficult vocabulary words immediately after they encountered them during passage reading. [¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"Group 1: Subjects were given the easy vocabulary passage and received no training. Group 2: Subjects were given the difficult vocabulary passage and received no training. Group 3: Subjects were given the difficult vocabulary and redun\xad dant information passage and received no training. Group 4: Subjects were given the difficult vocabulary passage and received vocabulary training. Group 5: Subjects were given the difficult vocabulary passage and received vocabulary and passage integration training.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"The final two treatments represented two vocabulary instruction techniques for teaching word meanings. Comparing the performance of students in these treatments with those who read the difficult vocabulary passage would clarify the contribution of vocabulary instruction to comprehension.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:

[¬s]"Children in each of three groups listened to stories individually with a familiar adult"
"Children attended four ses\xad sions at school over a three week period with several days intervening between ses\xad sions. The adults emphasized words natu\xad rally and maintained mutual focus with the child while reading. The adults re\xad sponded with positive regard and neutral comments to any talk by the child. Chil\xad dren in the comment group heard stories in which the adult made comments on the story."
" In Session 1, all children heard a warm-up story and became acquainted with the adult and the study's procedures. In Session 2, everyone heard two popular children's stories, Stories 1 and 2. In Ses\xad sion 3, all children heard two additional stories, Stories 3 and 4. In Session 4, they listened to Story 5. All children heard each of the stories in the same order.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]" The spe\xad cific goals of this study were to: determine if commenting had more im pact than ques\xad tioning or no specific interactive strategy on the complexity of the spontaneous utter\xad ances as well as the complexity of responses by children when listening to stories; de\xad termine if the types of spontaneous utter\xad ances made by children to aspects of the story content (story structure, story mean\xad ing) vary as a function of the adult\'s use of questions or comments during the story reading.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"Reader Preparation Two readers underwent training in read\xad ing stories to children prior to the study. Several practice sessions were held until each reader was comfortable with the story content, questions and comments for each story as well as with a common reading style. Each reader read to several children who were not included in the study. These readings were recorded, reviewed, and additional suggestions made to insure con\xad sistency in presentation by the two read\xad ers.[¬e]"']

[¬s]"In the strategy training, text comprehension[¬e]"', 'Page 13:
[¬s]" skills were explained, modeled and practised. Several strategies for instructional inter\xad action which are considered effective for the instruction of thinking and learning skills in recent research were applied (Brown & Palincsar, 1987; Collins et al., 1989; Paris & Jacobs, 1984). These instructional methods include, e.g., direct explanation, modeling, scaffolding, self-guided and cooperative practising, articulation and reflection."
"In the strategy plus coping training, the modeling, discussion and practising of the socioemotional coping strategies were integrated into the training of text-processing skills. Children’s negative emotional responses, avoidance tendencies, self-deprecatory causal attributions, and overreliance on social support were identified from video samples and discussed extensively. Non-task-oriented coping strategies were discussed and task- oriented coping strategies were m odeled as regards t o (1) a pproaching a nd beginning the task, (2) e xecuting the task, (3) terminating the ta sk, and (4) evaluating the total learning process. The training was sequenced to include both strategy and coping practice. Since the amount of training was kept constant across conditions, the children in strategy plus coping training received less practice in text-processing skills than children in the strategy alone condition (Vauras et al., 1992).[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 12:\n[¬s]" the aim of which was to enhance unskilled learners’ adoption and generalization of text-processing skills and to change their inadequate socioemotional coping tendencies in academic contexts.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 10:
[¬s]"On average, each CPD session included approximately 30 teachers and were led by two trainers. Sessions were highly interactive and practical in nature, requiring equipment to be set out and cleared away throughout the day. Two trainers were used to maximise interactions with the teachers, to help enable all teachers to participate in the practical investigations, and to minimise time lost due to logistical transitions between sections of the session. In addition, the intervention team requested that at least two teachers from each school participate in the CPD sessions to facilitate ongoing collaboration and mutual support. "
"In the CPD sessions, teachers were provided with a folder of reference materials to use when they returned to their classrooms and to assist with lesson planning. These materials included an agenda, the background to the strategies, exemplar teaching materials for each strategy, slides that could be used in the classroom, and instructions for all the investigations and problem-solving activities. All materials in the folder were available online through the programme’s secure web portal.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"Thinking, Doing, Talking Science (TDTS) is a teacher training intervention aimed at improving Year 5 science outcomes by making science lessons more effective. Teachers are trained to develop and teach challenging, enquiry-based science lessons that incorporate more practical activities, deeper thinking and discussion, and sharply focused recording.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 11:\n[¬s]"When implemented at scale, what is the impact of the Thinking, Doing, Talking Science (TDTS) programme on the (a) science knowledge attainment and (b) attitudes toward science of participating pupils at the end of the school year? This research question focused on two broad outcomes: pupil science knowledge attainment and attitudes toward science. TDTS is intended to help teachers create more engaging lessons that would result in increased pupil interest in, and self-efficacy toward, science. In addition, TDTS is focused on boosting science learning and enquiry skills. Hence, the ultimate outcome would be a meaningful increase in pupils’ knowledge of science.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]"To prepare the trainers for the delivery of the TDTS programme, the Oxford team worked with the trainers during four two-day, face-to-face sessions (eight days total for each trainer). These sessions were staggered throughout the year and preceded each teacher CPD session. They began in April prior to the intervention year, and subsequent sessions were timed to occur just prior to the delivery of TDTS CPD to teachers. The first train-the-trainers session included a briefing on the evaluation and details on the process for the trainers to recruit schools from their home regions into the study. In each train-the-trainer session, the Oxford team modelled the delivery of the upcoming CPD session, including engagement of the trainers in the science investigations and activities in the manner that they were to be used with teachers. Trainers were provided with, and trained on, materials for the upcoming CPD session: an agenda, presentation slides, trainer notes, and science investigation materials and instructions. The sessions were highly interactive, and the Oxford team leveraged the experience and knowledge of the trainers by soliciting feedback and applying that feedback in subsequent days of training. For example, the trainers encouraged the Oxford team to make explicit how each practical that was shared with the teachers linked to the key programme elements (illustrated in Figure 1). Discussions with the trainers also included thoughts on what to prioritise from the content of the latest national curriculum and how to infuse that content into the design of the CPD days. The intervention ethos and strategies remained the same, but the Oxford team updated the materials to be used with teachers based on feedback from the trainers.[¬e]"']
int_cost_ht:
['Page 32:
[¬s]"Cost Using the assumptions listed earlier (the trainers train three cohorts of teachers; each teacher uses the training with three years of pupils), the financial costs of the intervention were £1,671 per teacher or £29 per pupil (Table 20). Table 20: Financial costs to deliver TDTS to one cohort of teachers"
"The non-financial costs included four days of teacher supply time and laptops for trainers to use in the CPD sessions. Because sessions are a full day in term, and co-ordinated across schools that may have different schedules, supply cover was necessary for teacher attendance as opposed to sessions outside teaching hours or during school inset days. [¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"Cost The average costs of the intervention for one teacher was around £1,854, or £29 per pupil per year when averaged over three years. Costs of implementation may vary, particularly if implemented at a smaller scale. The non-financial costs included four days of teacher supply time per teacher and laptops for trainers to use in the CPD sessions.[¬e]"']

[¬s]"At the pupil level, several statistically significant differences occurred between the treatment and control groups (Table 7). First, pupils in the treatment schools were more likely to be ever FSM eligible (27.4%)[¬e]"', 'Page 26:
[¬s]"than pupils in the control schools (24.7%).9 Second, pupils in the treatment schools had slightly lower KS1 test scores.10 For example, the percent of pupils in treatment schools scoring 2A and above was 52.2% in mathematics and 55.2% in reading and writing compared with 54.6% in mathematics and 57.8% in reading and writing among pupils in control schools. The effect sizes of the differences at this cut-point (scoring 2A and above)—, 2.4 percentage points in mathematics and 2.5 in reading and writing—, are both approximately 0.06 using Cox’s Index (U.S. Department of Education, 2014). Finally, pupil IDACI also was lower in the treatment schools (46.9% in the low category) than in the control schools (40.3% in the low category).11 The additional analyses of outcome measures included these variables as covariates in the model."
"Table 7: Baseline comparison of pupils in the analysis sample[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 13:
[¬s]"The language experience approach appears to hold much promise for use with culturally disadvantaged pupils. The material is almost certain to be relevant and of at least some interest to the child, since the language used, even the topic discussed, is largely of his choosing. When ‘breaking the code' refers to traditional orthography, this task, too, should be simplified when the vocabulary, the morphological and the syntactical elements of the child's language are recorded carefully, accurately, and without reference to the non-standard character of his language."
"1. The child dictates his reaction to an experience. 2. The teacher records this reaction, utilizing the child's own language, and makes no effort to "correct" or change the pupil's wording. 3. The written record of his exper\xad ience becomes the child's reading material. He reads the language he. has just spoken,[¬e]"', 'Page 23:
[¬s]"The five Experimental I teachers received training in the use of the language experience approach to read\xad ing. They shared chart stories and related activities 'aimed at word analysis skills, techniques for enlarging vocabularies, etc,"
"Experimental I Topics - ’’ 1. Shared stories and related activities aimed at rhyming words, initial consonant work, comprehension skills, etc. 2. Guidance in teaching the language experience with presentation of published materials available (Lee & Allen, Learning to Read through Experience, Encyclopedia Britannica units, etc.)[¬e]"', 'Page 24:
[¬s]" Topics discussed by both groups together - 1~, Two f|r$t grad0 teachers,one famifJ^^Ttt+rthe language experience approach and the other experienced in the use of a basal series, shared their ideas about teaching first grade reading. 2. Discussion of the importance of comprehension skills and how to use them. 3. Discussion of aspects of critical reading pertinent to first grade. 4. Discussion of aspects of children's language relevant to teaching reading. 5. Study business - . -collected teacher information forms and teacher judgments of intellectual functioning and reading attitude. x -collected teacher supply orders ; and distributed supplies. ■ -explained and collected log sheets. -scheduled^testing dates and • OScAR-Rzvisits. -discussed test, survey and inventory" scones as they became available. [¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 13:\n[¬s]"The purpose of this study was to investigate the effectiveness of the "language experience" approach to beginning reading instruction when used with* "culturally disadvantaged" pupils. Achievement of pupils using this approach was ompared with achievement of pupils using other approaches to reading instruction.[¬e]"', 'Page 14:\n[¬s]"urban, first grade "disadvantaged children" learning to read by the "language experience" method would learn to read better and have a better attitude toward reading than their peers taught by conventional methods.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 1:\n[¬s]"Repeated Read-Aloud Events, Retellings, and Hands-On Science Activities[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 14:
[¬s]"The three informational picture books were read aloud three times each to groups of three or four children at the YWCA Child De- velopment Center."
" The books were read in this order: (a) What Is a Rainbow? (Arvetis & Palmer, 1983), (b) All the Colors of the Rainbow (Fowler, 1998), and (c) The Wonder of Light (Adkins, 1997). The third book, The Wonder of Light (Adkins, 1997), was read over a 2-week period, with part of the book being read each week.[¬e]"', 'Page 15:
[¬s]"Teacher read-aloud behaviors included (a) pointing to illustrations that depicted target vocabulary items or clariÞed concepts, such as pointing to a prism and following along the path shown where white light enters the prism and rainbow colors emerge; (b) asking children to repeat target words, such as ÒCan you say photons?Ó (c) asking questions, such as ÒHave you ever mixed yellow and blue paint together to make green?Ó and (d) using gestures and body language[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]" These studies have shown that dialogic reading can be carried out successfully in home and preschool set- tings and can result in higher scores on standardized assessments of expressive vocabulary and receptive measures of target words in picture books.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"This study continues the research on vocabulary acquisition from reading aloud books to young children, but unlike most research in this area, the focus is on preschool childrenÕs development of vocabulary from participation in interactive read-aloud events us- ing informational texts.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"By comparing these two reading conditions, the researcher hoped to distinguish between words learned from repeated interactive reading and words learned from repeated interactive reading plus retelling.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:\n[¬s]"(b) determine whether childrenÕs retelling of information books immediately after participating in read-aloud activities would enhance their learning of vocabulary, (c) determine whether hands-on science activities related to the bookÕs concepts and presented after book-related activities would improve vocabulary retention, (d) investigate the effects of such ac- tivities on childrenÕs scores on standardized vocabulary measures, the Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test (PPVT III) and the Expres- sive Vocabulary Test (EVT)[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 16:\n[¬s]"The scientist who helped plan the activities provided 2 hours of instruction and practice for the classroom teachers.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 70:\n[¬s]"The first treatment group was the case method group, in which students were taught the case method to improve their reading comprehension.[¬e]"', 'Page 72:\n[¬s]"The third group was the control group. In this group, the teachers did a variety of activities to facilitate students\' comprehension of each story. These activities included prereading discussions aimed at activating children\'s prior knowledge or experiences, bringing in extra reading materials to enrich students’ understanding, letting students do art work related to the topic of a story, and asking students to work in teams to find answers to teacher-specified questions.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: NA
int_objec_info: To compare the reading comprehension of students receiving a case method treatment approach to reading and students in the control group receiving traditional instruction.

int_desc_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"For the conditions involving school reading, the teacher or aide engaged in dia- logic book reading with children in groups of no more than 5children at atime. The number of children in school reading groups in each center required that mul- tiple groups be read to each day. Membership in aspecific reading group varied among children assigned to aschool reading condition onaday-to-day basis. ! Shared-reading sessions were scheduled to occur daily for approximately 10 min- utes per reading group. The teacher or aide conducting the dialogic reading group often took the children to alocation outside the classroom for these sessions. At other times, the reading groups were held in an isolated area of the classroom or when the other children were in adifferent location (e.g., playground). A second teacher or aide supervised the rest of the class during reading sessions. The six books listed in Table 1were provided to each classroom for use over the 6-week intervention. These books were chosen because of their potential to support vocab- ulary growth. Each had numerous colorful illustrations that could serve as abasis for introducing new vocabulary to children, and each book could support astory narrative through the illustrations alo[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Wehypothesized that children\'s oral language skills would be impacted positively in all three intervention groups compared to the contro[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"Teachers were trained to read to children in adialogic reading style by using a videotape training method (Arnold et al., 1994; Whitehurst et al., 1990) that was[¬e]"', 'Page 8:\n[¬s]"modeled closely on the direct training procedures used previously (e.g., Valdez- Menchaca & Whitehurst, 1992; Whitehurst et al., 1988). The videotape contained two assignments, described in Table 2. These procedures were presented as aset of guidelines and were followed by taped vignettes of adult-child book reading that exemplified these guidelines. The version of the videotape used with teachers con- tained asecond section with guidelines specific to using dialogic reading in groups (see Table 2). The final section of the videotape consisted of vignettes of adult- child reading that did not conform to the guidelines. Teachers were asked by the trainer to criticize the reading presented in these vignettes according to the dialogic reading guidelines and to indicate what the adult reader should have done differ- ently. Following the videotape, the trainer engaged teachers in aone-on-one role- play, which involved presenting the teacher with various examples of child behav- ior, and providing the teacher with feedback on her use of the dialogic reading guidelines. The whole training session took about 30 minutes per trainee for Part 1 and 20 minutes for Part 2. Part 1and Part 2training sessions were separated by 3 weeks. All teachers were trained during the school[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"Shared-reading sessions were scheduled to occur da[¬e]"']
int_leng_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"ly for approximately 10 min- utes per reading[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]" Dialogic reading involves several changes in the way adults typically read books to children. Central to these chang\xad es is a shift in roles. During typical shared- reading, the adult reads and the child listens, but in dialogic reading the child learns to be\xad come the storyteller. The adult assumes the role of an active listener, asking questions, adding information, and prompting the child to increase the sophistication of her or his de\xad scriptions of the picture book. As the child becomes accustomed to her or his role as the storyteller, the adult shifts more of the re\xad sponsibility for telling the story to the child.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]" examine the differential efficacy of center-based dia\xad logic reading and typical shared-reading with children from low-income families[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Volunteer readers received training in dialog\xad ic reading style using a videotape training meth\xad od (Arnold et al., 1994; Whitehurst, Arnold, & Lonigan, 1990) modeled closely on previously used direct training procedures (e.g., Whitehurst et al., 1988). The videotape presented the two phases of dialogic reading."\n"Follow\xad ing the videotape, the trainer engaged trainees in one-on-one role-plays, which involved pre\xad senting the trainee with various examples of child behavior, and providing the trainee with feedback on her or his use of the dialogic reading guidelines. The Phase 1 training ses\xad sion took about 30 minutes per trainee and the Phase 2 session, which was introduced at the start of the 4th week of intervention for all children in the dialogic reading group, lasted about 20 minutes.[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 12:\n[¬s]"19 sessions at 10-15 minutes per sessio[¬e]"', 'Page 4:\n[¬s]" daily[¬e]"']
int_freq_info: The goal was to carry the intervention out daily, however, see highlighted material which shows on average children received 19 sessions rather than the 30 aimed for.

int_desc_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]" The experimental group, identified as the Strategies Group, was introduced to the four comprehension strategies\x97predicting (guessing what will happen), questioning (asking questions to clarify ideas), clarifying (making clear an unknown word or idea), and summarizing (retelling what has happened)-following the transactional strategies instruction (TSI) approach. For example, we talked about the strategies with the students and modeled how we would be using them during discussion in our reading groups. As we read aloud, we modeled predicting what was about to happen from the pictures and the chapter titles, stopping to ask questions when appropriate, clarifying difficult words or parts of a selection, and summarizing at appropriate places in the text. We then had the children take turns going through the process. We continued this until we felt that the children were ready to work in their assigned groups.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"The purpose of this research study was to determine whether students who were taught specific research-based strategies using a transactional strategies instruction (TSI) approach (Pressley, El-Dinary, Gaskins, Schuder, Bergman, Almasi, & Brown, 1992) would (a) improve in comprehension achievement, and (b) be more engaged during reading groups.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: NA
int_dur_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]"The research study was conducted over eight weeks during the last quarter of the school year for a total of 180 minutes of instruction per week.[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]"My co-researcher and I spent two days a week during regularly scheduled reading sessions with students from two fourth grade classrooms.[¬e]"']
int_leng_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]"Each of us worked with two groups of eight students for forty-five minutes each,[¬e]"']

Two groups of eight children from one classroom became the expe[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"Two types of speciÞc knowledge were trained: knowledge of speciÞc informational content from instructed text and knowledge of text structure conventions. The lessons were organized around[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"four main activities: activating prior knowledge on the topic, elaborating information contained in the text, mapping the textÕs main ideas, and analysis of the textÕs structure. The instruction was delivered using a direct explana- tion format, in contrast to the dialogue format described for the following program. The program began with a four-lesson introduction to the speciÞc proce- dures and content used in the program. During these lessons, students were introduced to the four main activities and how they would be used in the comprehension training. Students were taught, for instance, how to map ideas in a passage, the difference between superordinate and subordinate informa- tion, different paragraph functions in a text (e.g., introductory, explanatory, narrative, deÞnitional, transitional), different organizational patterns in text (e.g., chronological, cause Ðeffect, compareÐ contrast), different patterns of cohesive relationship among text elements (e.g., ellipsis, anaphora), and how to recognize signal words that give clues to the authorÕs plan and overall text organization. The remaining 21 lessons involved instruction in and practice on the four activities using seven different instructional texts, all of an expository nature. Three lessons were devoted to each text. [¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"On a more general level, the TCS Program explicitly instructs these disabled readers on the form and structure of connected expository text. Subjects learn how to represent a passageÕs ideas graphically, serving as a useful mnemonic device, and are trained to recognize and identify a number of structural conventions that authors use for different purposes. Subjects are trained to recognize the overall structure of a text, the most common organizational patterns in text, different paragraph functions, and cohesive ties and signal words within single sentences and to consider the authorÕs apparent plan. The teacher dialog for this program was developed from examples found in Devine (1986).[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]" The Þrst comprehension pro- gram, the Text Content and Structure (TCS) Program, was designed to reme- diate a deÞcient knowledge base, forcing disabled readers to elaborate and further process new text knowledge.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:\n[¬s]"The goal is to foster better representation of new information in memory and more active use and integration of new knowledge during the act of reading connected text.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: NA
int_approach_ht: ['Page 12:\n[¬s]"The instruc- tion was administered by special education teachers who taught pairs of chil- dren matched for level of reading skill. [¬e]"']
int_when_info: Study did not always take place in a school, therefore it is unclear whether it was conducted during regular school hours.

int_freq_ht: ['Page 12:\n[¬s]" Sessions were held four times a week[¬e]"']

"The Oracy Skills Framework (Appendix 1) identifies the skills needed to be able to communicate effectively in a range of settings and styles, using a wide vocabulary with fluency. int_desc_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"Lessons were designed around texts being used in the classrooms, and thus students in all approaches dealt with the same texts. These texts were the five core selections that made up one theme within the basal reader in use in the school. Each selection was the core text in a weekly les son plan that also included reading of another shorter text and activities in fluency, writing, vocabulary, word study, self-selected reading, and other typical language arts practices. The part of the five-day lesson plan labeled guided comprehension consisted of reading the core text with program-provided, scripted teacher questions. In this study, we used the guided comprehension slice of the weekly lesson plan to implement the lessons that we de veloped. Each lesson occupied a total of 45 to 75 minutes"
"For the second year of the study, the same lessons for the five narrative selections were implemented with a new cohort of students and three expository text lessons were added. W[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"Content Approach Content instruction focused student attention on the content of the text through general, meaning-based questions about the text. Reading was stopped and dis cussion initiated at purposely selected points when, for example, a key character was introduced, some impor tant event had occurred, or where we judged some con fusion might arise for readers. This method is based on the QtA approach (Beck & McKeown, 2006; Beck et al., 1996). At each stopping point, the teacher provided an initiating question to start the discussion. These open ended questions were designed to make public the im portant idea in a text segment (e.g., "What's going on here?" "How does all this connect with what we read earlier?"). Most stops also included a follow-up question that the teacher could use to focus on the key ideas from that portion of text. These follow-ups (e.g., "Can any one add to that?" "What does that mean?") were used as needed to elicit additional information.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"The goal of this work is a greater understanding of the extent to which instruction focused on content or on strategies enhances students\' comprehension of spe cific texts and their independent comprehension abil ity. F[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]" On the first day, treatment subjects were given instruction in text specific vocabulary. An overhead projector was used to display four World Book (1989) entries; earthquake, crater, avalanche, and sulfur dioxide. Subjects and the instructor read and discussed the four entries. Students, working in pairs, then drew a diagram of the relationships among the four words. Four pairs of students were asked to describe their diagrams to the entire groups. One pair of students, for example, drew a large triangle to represent a mountain and then placed geometric shapes representing each word in appropriate places on the triangle. Each geometric shape was labeled with one of the four vocabulary words. For example, an oval near the top of the triangle was labeled crater, a narrow rectangle on the side of the triangle was labeled avalanche. On the second day, subjects in the treatment group briefly reviewed the vocabulary words presented on the previous day. As a group, subjects made a semantic map of the word volcano. Relationships among features of the semantic map were discussed. Then the World Book entry on volcanoes was projected. It contained reference to and information about the four remaining vocabulary words, volcano, lateral blast, magma, and eruption. Again, subjects and the instructor read the text and discussed the selected vocabulary. Then subjects were asked to use the information from the semantic map and what they remembered from the discussions and the diagram to write a summary paragraph about volcanoes.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"The present study used authentic text to investigate the effects of teaching text specific vocabulary on reading comprehension and readers\' ability to make causal connections while reading difficult expository text.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]"All testing was conducted by the classroom teacher who had been trained by the first author.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"Self-Instruction. The program was divided into two parts (see Table 1). For the first 13 sessions, children were taught the general self-instructional procedure and some specific reading comprehension strategies; for the final 7 sessions, students practiced all the strategies together."
"five questions that chil\xad dren had to put to themselves when they were coping with a reading task: 1. "STOP. What do I have to do?" 2. "THINK and DECIDE. I have to think which is the best way to do the task." 3. "CHECK. Am I doing it the right way?" 4. "CONFIRM: Yes, I am doing it the right way." 5. "EVALUATE." "a) If I am mistaken, next time I will do it better." "b) Good! I have done a good job." The instructor modeled the proce\xad dure to the children with a known task, explained its benefits in coping with the reading tasks, and asked one of the children do the same thing with another similar task."
"In the first two sessions, the chil\xad dren were also given a short explana\xad tion about three different structures in expository prose: collection, com\xad parison, and description (Meyer, 1985)"
"The next 11 sessions were dedicated to teaching children specific reading\xad comprehension strategies at the pace of two sessions per strategy, except for the last one. The strategies were the following: activating previous knowledge before reading, preview\xad ing texts, self-questioning, clarifying, and mapping ideas."
"Strategies Used During Intervention in Self-Instruction and Self-lnstruction-Plus-Attribution Conditions Strategy component Session Self-instruction General self-instruction procedure, text structure 1-2 Activate previous knowledge 3-4 Preview of text 5-6 Self-question 7-8 Clarify 9-10 Mapping ideas 11-13 Practice of strategies 14-20[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"In the second part of the inter\xad vention, children practiced all the strategies they had been taught. They activated previous knowledge before reading the text, previewed the text content, read the text, clarified read\xad ing difficulties, formulated questions, and elaborated an idea map. Recipro\xad cal teaching procedures, such as the ones used by Palincsar and Brown (1984), were used with small modifi\xad cations. These modifications consisted of having a more expert child model the right strategy by thinking aloud when reading a paragraph, and then asking him or her to designate another classmate to do the same with an\xad other paragraph. This expert help was progressively withdrawn, and children"
"simply applied the right strategy in their turn. All children participated in the reading-comprehension strategy instruction.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"Young children’s responses to one-to-one story readings in school settings[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"To date, most of the research on one-to-one read-aloud activities has concerned interactive behavior between parents and children in mid\xad dle-class homes. The research reported here fo\xad cused on one-to-one reading of stories to children (a) from lower socioeconomic status (SES) homes and (b) in school settings.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"This study was designed to investigate whether frequent one-to- one readings in a school setting would increase the number and complexity of comments and questions from children of low socioeconomic status (SES). [¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"The pur\xad pose of the present study was to investigate the effects on children from lower socioeconomic backgrounds of one-to-one readings in school settings that encouraged interaction between the teacher and child. Specifically, the study was designed to answer the following questions:"
"1. Do frequent one-to-one story readings at school increase the number of ques\xad tions and comments children make about stories? 2. Do frequent one-to-one story readings at school increase the type and com\xad plexity of questions and comments made about stories? 3. Do repeated readings of the same story elicit different types of questions and comments than a series of readings of unrepeated books?[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]" The research assistants who ad\xad ministered the treatment attended two training sessions. At the first, they reviewed the guidesheets describing the procedure for read\xad ing stories to children and for prompting re\xad sponses to the literature (see Table 1). They then simulated the treatment with each other. At the second training session they practiced the treatment with children. Correct administration of the treatment was monitored by listening to tape recordings of the story reading sessions. The research assistants who worked with the control group attended a separate training session.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"The present investigation sought to build on the work of others in creating a program in which children are involved with storybooks in a social interactive environment. It included various storybook reading and emergent literacy strategies which have proven to be beneficial in literacy development.[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]"1. Quiet book reading. During quiet book reading, teachers and students all se- lected one or two books each to look at for a short period of time. 2. Teacher directed literature activities. The format in each day\'s teacher-directed literature activity was that of the DLTA, which provided a framework of ques- tion, prediction, and discussion both before and after a story reading. Teachers had a variety of activities suggested for sharing books with children from which they could choose. Some of these included: (a) reading for pleasure; (b) role playing and retelling stories; (c) repeated readings of favorite stories; (d) shared book experiences, which included children\'s participation in story readings; (e) using literature related to content area subjects; and (f) other ideas prepared by the teachers themselves. Activities included such events as preparing and eating bread and jam after listening to the story Bread and Jam for Frances (Hoban, 1960). Stories were told using puppets, feltboard characters, and props. Chil- dren were encouraged to model storytelling techniques used by the teacher during the recreational reading periods. 3. The recreational reading period. Children in the experimental group were free to select any materials from the Literacy Center (or library corner) during recre- ational reading. They were allowed to work either individually or with others. The area was designed to contain books, magazines, roll movies, story cassettes, Big Books, Viewmasters, feltboard characters, and puppets. Blank paper, mark- ers, glue, crayons, and pencils were available so children could create their own books. The purpose was to spend independent time involved with literature and literature related materials. 4. Summary of the day. The summary of the day convened the entire class for 5 to 10 minutes of discussion about the story reading events that had taken place with the youngsters in the experimental group during the day.[¬e]"', 'Page 9:\n[¬s]" the program components, which included: (a) quiet book reading, (b) a teacher-directed literature activity, (c) a recreational reading period, and (d) a summary of the day.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 60:\n[¬s]"Dialogic Reading (Whitehurst, Falco et al., 1988) is an oral language intervention through which children are encouraged to interact with the storybook. During book reading the teacher or adult asks the children questions, encourages answers and helps the children to develop more sophisticated responses to the text. After a few sessions, children are asked to become more active participants in the book reading experience by becoming the storytellers. Appendix A provides the intervention schedule including the list of titles utilized in this study. The storybooks selected for use in this study were based on the recommendations of the creators of the Dialogic Reading technique (Whitehurst et al., 1994). The following is a description of key components of the Dialogic Reading technique followed by a description of prompts used during reading: Key Components Prompt. The children are prompted to say something about the book or page (for example, "What\'s this? Tell me about this page?). Individual students are called on to offer comments about what \x93story\x94 is being told on a given page. Evaluate. Individual responses are evaluated by the teacher and the child is asked another question that will pinpoint specifics about the text. Expand. When a child offers a response, the teacher adds information to the response so that all the children can hear the details of the story. Repeat. The teacher repeats the child\x92s responses to make sure the other children hear the response. This also gives the child a chance to clarify his/her response if desired.[¬e]"', 'Page 61:\n[¬s]"Completion. This type of prompt is used when the teacher leaves a blank at the end of the sentence in order to let the child predict the final word. This is most often used when working with rhyming material, but can also be used with predictable text. Recall. This type of prompt requires asking questions about what occurred on a specific page or to summarize the main parts of a story. Recall questions can also be asked prior to reading a storybook. Open ended. This type of questioning involves asking students to describe what is happening in a specific picture in the book. This prompt works best with storybooks that contain richly detailed illustration. W prompts. These prompts simply refer to asking what, when, where, why, and how questions. Distancing. For this component, children are asked to relate the pictures or words to their own life experiences. Distancing questions help children with verbal fluency, conversation abilities, and narrative skills (for example, "Tell me about a time you felt afraid").[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 16:\n[¬s]"Dialogic Reading (Whitehurst, Falco et al., 1988), and other similar interventions designed to increase oral language skills in young children, have been found to increase phonological awareness indirectly through increasing oral language ability (Lonigan, 2006). Dialogic Reading is a shared storybook reading activity developed to offer a context for interactive dialogue between an adult and children. This technique encourages active participation by the child in telling and re-telling the story. Language skills are reinforced by asking questions, assisting children with expanding on their responses, and providing specific praise. This technique allows the adult and children to jointly construct meaning from the text while supporting the development of a more sophisticated language system.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"A modified version of a technique known as semantic mapping (Hanf 1971) was used in the context-teaching programme. Semantic mapping is a visual strategy for enhancing vocabulary development. The target word is written at the centre of the map and related words written in boxes connected to this. The theoretical rationale for using semantic maps to teach word meanings is the theory that people store information about words in the form of semantic networks.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 125:\n[¬s]"The control and experimental groups received reading instruction within the district framework for language arts. In addition, the researcher taught the experimental group four metacognitive strategies and the value and purpose o f the strategies."\n"Students in the experimental group received fifteen weeks o f explicit metacognitive strategy instruction. M etacognitive strategy instruction took place three times a w eek for fifteen to twenty minutes. The researcher modeled each strategy in a regular classroom setting using readily available fifth grade materials. Students were given an opportunity to practice strategies independently and in small groups. W hen the fifteen-w eek treatm ent period was concluded the researcher provided the comparison teacher w ith explicit strategy lessons to model and teach think-aloud, visualization, activation o f prior knowledge, and questioning w ith the control group. Lessons included explanation o f strategies’ purpose and time for student practice.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 125:\n[¬s]"M etacognitive strategy instruction strives to provide all students with strategic methods to construct meaning from text, regardless o f ability. int_name_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"An Investigation of Imagery as a Technique for Greater Retention of Science Vocabulary Terms by Fifth-Grade Students[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 79:\n[¬s]"The subjects assigned to the Imagery group listened as the teacher gave a definition for each science term followed by two examples or instances in which the term was used correctly. The subjects were directed to picture the examples and instances as the teacher presented them. The subjects were then directed to make up a sentence describing the pictured application of the science terms. Next, the teacher asked two subjects to share their sentences and to tell why they chose to construct the particular picture described in their sentences.[¬e]"', 'Page 80:\n[¬s]"The Control group received no direct instruction. On day one, the Control group received a list of the science terms and their meanings with the directions that they would be tested on these on Friday.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 19:
[¬s]"The purpose of this study was to compare the effects of the Imagery Method with"
"a Control Method of vocabulary instruction on fifth graders’ short-term and long-term retention and sus\xad tained learning of science vocabulary. The following questions guided this study: 1. Which of the three methods provides for greatest gain in short-term retention of fifth-grade science vocab\xad ulary terms as measured by the Open-ended Definitions Test, the Sentence-Generation Test, the Literal Comprehension Multiple-choice Test, and the Inferential Comprehension Multiple-choice Test? 2. Which of the three methods provides for greatest gain in long-term retention of fifth-grade science vocabulary terms as measured by the Open-ended Definitions Test, the Sentence-Generation Test, the Literal Comprehension Multiple\xad choice Test, and the Inferential Comprehension Multiple-choice Test? 3. Which of the three methods provides for greatest sustained learning of fifth-grade science vocabulary terms as measured by the Open-ended Definitions Test, by the Sentence- Generation Test, the Literal Comprehension Multiple-choice Test, and the Inferential Comprehension Multiple-choice Test?[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"The purpose of this study was to determine the effec\xad tiveness of Imagery as a technique for greater retention of science vocabulary terms.[¬e]"']

comp_anal_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]"A planned multivariate analysis of covariance on these data was not possible because there was a significant Treatment X MET-1 interaction in the two-way ANOVA with treatment and MET-1 as factors and MET-2 as the dependent variable. Instead, a multivariate linear regression was performed with MET-1, Circus-A, treatment, and site regressed on MET-2 and Circus-B. Results are presented in Table 2. The strongest predictor of MET-2 and Circus-B was MET-1. Moreover, both pretests were significant predictors of both posttests in the univariate and multivariate tests. Neither treatment nor site had significant effects on either posttest. However, there was a significant MET-1 X Treatment interaction in the univariate case with MET-2 as the dependent variable. The interaction occurred as follows: in the home and school and school only treatments, students scoring lowest on MET-1 performed worse on MET-2 than the control group, while students scoring highest on MET-1 performed better on MET-2 than the control group; for the home only treatment, students scoring lowest on MET- 1 scored higher on MET-2 than students in the control group, while students scoring highest on MET-1 performed the same as students in the control group."
"There was a significant MET-1 X Site interaction in the multivariate case. Urban students scored
highest on all tests. The village students scored higher than the collector students on both pretests both
lower on both posttests.[¬e]"']
comp_anal_info: Pre-test results assessed in the regression analyses  In sub-test, location (urban vs rural) also assessed but unclear how used in regression

int_name_info: Language development program for culturally deprived preschool children
int_desc_ht: ['Page 6:\n[¬s]"The format of this language development program con\xad sists mainly of the following six activities: 1. A formal, highly-structured language development period placed in settings that are psychologically near to the child. 2. Story time with materials used relating to the context of the language development period. 3. Visual discrimination exercises based on words and ideas presented in the language development period. 4. Auditory discrimination consisting of various games built around material and activities presented during language development period, 5. A period devoted to developing facility in under\xad standing numbers and quantitative expressions. 6. Interest centers such as housekeeping, gas station, block, modeling clay, and dress-up centers.[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: Black children were learning 220 most common words and 95 nouns (Dolch’s Basic Sight Vocabulary of 220 words and Dolch's list of the 95 Most Commonly Used Nouns) used in the primary school reading material.   The format of this language development program con­ sists mainly of the following six activities  1. A formal, highly-structured language development period placed in settings that are psychologically near to the child. 2. Story time with materials used relating to the context of the language development period. 3. Visual discrimination exercises based on words and ideas presented in the language development period. 4. Auditory discrimination consisting of various games built around material and activities presented during language development period, 5. A period devoted to developing facility in understanding numbers and quantitative expressions. 6. Interest centers such as housekeeping, gas station, block, modeling clay, and dress-up centers.

"3. What are the differential effects of the two oral reading instructional routines, if any, on reader develop\xad ment (e.g., fluency, self-correction, accuracy, comprehen\xad sion, and benefit to readers of differing abilities)?"

int_training_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]"Four teachers agreed to participate in the study and receive special teacher training sessions taught by the researchers prior to and during the experiment."\n" During the training sessions, the four teachers (two assigned to SBE and two to ORL) were provided with materials and lessons for planning and implement\xad ing the two experimental instructional procedures. In addition to the training sessions, the researchers devel\xad oped, with the assistance of a graduate research assis\xad tant, a set of daily basal lesson guides tied to the district- adopted Houghton-Mifflin basal readers.[¬e]"']
base_diff_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"To check the effectiveness of the random assign\xad ment procedures for the two experimental conditions, students were administered three reading subtests of the Iowa Test of Basic Skills (ITBS) during the first week of school and prior to the onset of the study. The ITBS Word Analysis, Vocabulary, and Comprehension subtests were analyzed using a Wilks multivariate test of signifi\xad cance. This analysis indicated no significant initial differ\xad ences between the two groups on the ITBS reading sub\xad test pretests: Word Analysis KI, 78) = .64, p>.42; Vocabulary KI,78) = .03, p>.85; and Comprehension KI,78) = .66, p>.42 "\n"However, there was a significant initial difference among all three blocks of reading ability on each of the ITBS reading subtest pretest scores as would be expected as a result of random assignment from blocks to treatments: Word Analysis K2,78) = 63-8, p>.0001; Vocabulary K2.78) = 77.6, £>.0001; and Comprehension K2.78) “ 100.8, £>.0001. No significant treatment-by-block interactions were found between the two experimental groups on the ITBS reading subtest pretest scores: Word Analysis K2, 78) = 1.47 , £>.24; Vocabulary K2.78) = 1.25, £>.92; and Comprehension K2,78) = 1.39, £>.26.[¬e]"']

int_training_ht:
['Page 34:
[¬s]"Teachers in the CR and CR + Lessons conditions met with the researcher prior to the beginning of the project to learn more about the CR approach, as well as the design, procedures, and schedule for the study. During these meetings teachers were presented with the CR model, introduced to the CR strategies (see Waggoner et al., 1995), and given various reading materials, including a transcript of one CR discussion with instructive comments regarding the moves of the discussion participants. Teachers also saw video clips of exemplary CR discussions conducted by other teachers. Teachers from the CR + Lessons condition had an additional meeting with the researcher, where the lessons on argumentation were discussed. Specifically, both teachers from CR + Lessons condition practiced delivering the lessons in front of the researcher. Questions regarding the content and possible student responses were addressed.[¬e]"', 'Page 35:

"A two-factor ANOVA was performed to examine whether the average reading ability differed across the treatment conditions. Reading Ability was used as a dependent variable, with Method and Grade being the explanatory factors. Grade factor was statistically significant (p = .01).[¬e]"']

int_name_info: Shared Book Experience Program (Whole language approach, Holdaway)
int_desc_ht: ['Page 102:\n[¬s]"Format of experimental treatment. The daily program of shared book experiences sessions follows this format (Holdaway, 1979, pp. 72-73): 1. Welcoming activity: reading aloud of poem, chant, or song; use of enlarged material (printed matter large enough for group viewing). 2. Favorite stories: re-reading of stories, usually by request; unison participation; discussion and exploration of syn\xad tax. 3. Language activity:- exploring language through games, riddles, puzzles. 4. New story: introduction of new story for the day; words pointed to as they are read aloud; language experiences shared. 5. Independent reading: self-selection of old favorites to[¬e]"', 'Page 103:\n[¬s]"90 read; engagement in literary activities of choice. 6. Expression: art and writing activities; group drama. The major sharing session of new book experiences corresponds to the bedtime story setting of the developmental learning model. Additionally, language experiences are included that reflect explor\xad ation of the real world for the purposes of writing the children’s own stories (Holdaway, 1979, p. 71).[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: Simulating the Bedtime story scenario, literature is introduced to the class in a storyreading setting (compared to the comparison group which learned alphabets one by one).
int_objec_ht: NA
int_objec_info: Improve emergent literacy  linguistic, orthographic, and grapho-phonemic literacy

base_diff_ht: ['Page 132:\n[¬s]"Preliminary .b-tests were computed to determine whether initial differences existed between experimental and comparison groups (see Table 2). There were no significant differences (j> _> .05) between the groups on pretest scores of Test of Language Development Total (TOLD-P), Book Handling Knowledge Task (BHKT), or Metropolitan Achievement Test, Reading Instructional Tests (Primer level) (MAT). When TOLD-P composite scores were examined separately, significant differences between groups (_p < .05) were noted for three of the four composites: Listening, Speaking, and Syntax. No significant differences between groups were found on pretest Semantics composite scores. Although there was an initial difference between groups on three TOLD-P composite scores, the difference was not substantial enough to affect the TOLD-P Total score.[¬e]"', 'Page 133:\n[¬s]"Table 2 Preliminary tests-between Experimental and Comparison Groups[¬e]"']
comp_anal_ht: ['Page 132:\n[¬s]"Pretest scores were subsequently adjusted with ANCOVA procedures.[¬e]"', 'Page 98:\n[¬s]"Accordingly, establishment of equivalence of the experimental and control groups was made by the following pro\xad cedures: 1. There was inherent control for sex, socio-economic status, and cultural and religious orientation in subject selection. 2. Pretest scores on measures of the outcome dependent vari\xad ables were used as a covariate[¬e]"']
