base_diff_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]" Children in both groups had initial PPVT-III standard scores of < 85.[¬e]"', 'Page 9:\n[¬s]" Thirty-six children (mean age 57.16 months) were selected to receive the say-tell-do supplemental instruction, based on their Peabody Picture Vocabulary Test -III (PPVT-III; Dunn & Dunn, 1997) standard scores (< 85) and teacher nomina- tions, based on observations of language use. All demonstrated vulnerabilities in their vocabulary development due to identi\x1eed special needs (69%), including developmental delays or at-risk factors, such as diverse home language or low income. Four children resided in homes in which English and another language were spoken; however, all of the children spoke English. A com- parable group of children (n = 38; mean age 52.81; 19 males, 19 females) was selected as a nonintervention control group. These children also were participating in a similar ERF program and receiving daily instruction in early literacy essential skills from an experienced, trained teach- ing staff, but no supplemental, small-group vocabulary instruction. All children in both groups were identi\x1eed as residing in low-income homes.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]"Phase 1 comprised pretesting and whole-class preparatory activities. Students wrote essays telling what they knew or thought about the topic of "giving.” Three to 5 days later, teachers reviewed the plan of activities, introduced the story with a prepared, three-sentence synopsis, and read aloud the first page of the six-page story. Students then read the remainder of the story independently."
"Phase 2 comprised the conduct of the lit\xad erature unit under experimental conditions (see Table 4). It commenced the day after students read the story and lasted 4 days."
"On day 2, the teacher con\xad ducted instructional conversation lessons with the instructional conversation-only group and the literature log + instructional conversation group."
"For the literature logs, teachers met the group briefly and gave them a prompt ask\xad ing students to write about personal expe\xad riences related to Louella's experiences in the story.[¬e]"', 'Page 12:
[¬s]"In the instructional conversation lessons, teachers attempted through discussion to clarify the factual content of the story and develop students' understandings of the more sophisticated concept of giving, that is, giving of oneself."
"All students in the study (including stu\xad dents in the control group) also engaged in independent "read and study" about the story "Louella's Song.""
"Phase 3 comprised posttesting. Students took the same comprehension test and com\xad pleted the same essays used for the pretest.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"examined the effects of two literature studies components: litera\xad ture logs and instructional conversations.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]"A detailed set of lesson plans, developed by the first au\xad thor and the participating teachers, de\xad scribed instructional procedures for each treatment condition. The first author briefed each participating teacher just prior to the beginning of the study, maintained daily contact throughout the study, and de\xad briefed each teacher immediately following the study's conclusion. All communication between the researcher and participating teachers indicated that treatment conditions were maintained and procedures were properly carried out across all five class\xad rooms.[¬e]"', 'Page 2:
[¬s]"Teachers had completed 1 year of literature log and instructional conversation training. [¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]" Led by two instructional advisors, one of whom spearheaded the original de\xad velopment of the transition program (Gisela O'Brien), the team meets twice a month throughout the year to study instructional components, view videotape and live dem\xad onstrations, plan units, and analyze student work. Advisors coteach and assist teachers in the classroom daily. At the time of the study, the teachers were completing their first year of participation on the research and development team.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 3:
[¬s]" the clinician was in an active mode, which means that the software was used with instructor enhancement that included asking students additional questions on the four levels of discourse skills, providing additional information, and encouragingverbalization of responses to all questions asked by the computer and/or the clinician (See Appendix A).[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"a touch sensitive screen for imputing responses [%I' is appropriate and effective with young children. Words & Concept Series uses a core vocabulary of forty nouns to integrate language and concept training with activities that offer training in vocabulary, categorization, word identification by function, word association, concept-same/alike,and concept-different.Inspection of these software packages shows that they provide some receptive training on the f m t three levels of discourse skills according to the Blank et al. model [2[¬e]"', 'Page 6:
[¬s]"Words & Concepts Series does not require verbal responses from participants for response choice. Instead,responses are made by pointing to the correct picture using a Touch Window when specific questions for teaching the nouns and concepts are asked with voice output from a speech synthesizer. Discourse skills, however, require not only an understanding of language, but the expression of language in appropriate responses to questions. This aspect is not addressed in Words & Concepts Series; thus this software can not by itself be expected to improvediscourse skills which require verbal responses.Since the ultimateobjec- tive of this study was to provide students, not only with an understanding of words and concepts, but the capability of expressing this information in dialogue with their teachers, Words & Concept Series was used with enhancement. Enhance- ment involved clinicians giving additional instructions (e.g., new information, asking additional questions) and requiring the students to verbalize as well as point to their picture choice.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"During regular morning Head Start classroom activities, students, paired in groups of two, were taken by a clinician assigned to their classroom for computer- assisted training."
"Instruction occurred for twenty minutes, twice a week for a period of twelve weeks. A break of approximately one and a half weeks for university and Head Start vacations occurred after a consecutive ten week period. Computers were not[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"available to students outside this training with one exception. Students in one Head Start class had computer access for alphabet instruction the last two weeks of this study.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]" It was anticipated that the children in this environment would show an increase in receptive vocabulary based on the software, and an increase in expressive language (discourse skills) based on enhancement procedures used with the software.[¬e]"']

The clinicianswere only provided with information concerningthe general nature of this study. The specific objectives were not discussed.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 7:
[¬s]" Following pretesting, the experimenter read the storybook twice. The second reading was introduced by the experimenter saying that this was such a nice book that they should read it again. Children were asked whether they wanted to hear the story again: none of the children declined."
" In[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"the questioning condition, the experimenter asked a what- or where-question after reading each target word in the narrative. For example, after reading the target item angling, the experimenter asked ‘What is Arthur doing?’ If children responded with the target word then the experimenter said ‘O.K. ’ and continued reading the book. If children failed to use the target word, the experimenter requested ‘ Can you tell me the word I used when I was reading the book?’ If children still did not use the target word, the experimenter labelled the target word. The questions were interspersed during the reading narrative"
"All children in the repeated- reading and the questioning conditions participated in a second session that occurred the following day. Children were read the story in the same manner as in the first session, and then were post-tested for expressive and receptive vocabulary. In all reading conditions, the experimenter listened attentively to children’s comments. Moreover, children’s queries, if any, were answered with variations of the prompt: ‘ That’s interesting, what do you think ? ’ Thus, although children’s comments and queries were not directly encouraged, they were not discouraged.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]"The present study was conducted to assess the effect of didactic techniques used during storybook reading on young children’s acquisition of new vocabulary introduced in storybooks.[¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"In essence, the labelling questions require children to imitate, that is, reproduce words heard in the narrative."
" This type of questioning behaviour is also interesting because it may provide some empirical evidence of the role of imitation in vocabulary acquisition."
" The present research allowed an exploration of the role of imitation in the acquisition of novel words. The present research was designed to assess whether specific reading behaviours would have a different impact on receptive and expressive vocabulary, and whether this differential impact changes with age. The present experiment allowed an empirical verification of the assertion by Whitehurst & DeBaryshe (1989) that receptive vocabulary might be more sensitive to variables such as frequency of language exposure, whereas expressive vocabulary might be more sensitive to variables such as imitation. In the present study, active responding was elicited by asking questions during book reading and exposure to novel words was manipulated by reading the book either once or three times.[¬e]"']

int_leng_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]" In the first session, lasting 20 minutes[¬e]"']
base_diff_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"There were 15 boys and 15 girls in each age group, and gender was counterbalanced across reading conditions. The mean age for the three- and four-year-olds was 3 ; 6 (s.D. = 5 mo) and 4; 8 (s.D. = 3 mo), respectively. Children were recruited from daycares located in a middle-class neighbour\xad hoods in Ottawa, Canada. Ninety percent of children were Caucasiuan and the remainder were Asian. Parents reported that they read to their children frequently (M = 7-1 times per week). Storybook reading frequency at home did not vary or interact with any of the independent variables (Fs < 1). Parents (N = 32) who agreed to provide information about socio-economic status were middle-class (M = 48 5 on the Hollingshead Four Factor Index; Hollingshead, 1975).[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]" designed to improve the spoken language ability of children during the transition from nursery to primary school. It is targeted at children with relatively poor spoken language skills. Three sessions per week are delivered to groups of two to four children starting in the final term of nursery and continuing in the first two terms of reception in primary school. Children in primary school also attend an additional two 15-minute individual sessions per week."
"This report evaluates the I CAN-led model for the 30-week programme described above and also a shorter 20-week version delivered only in reception year. The impact of these two programmes on the language skills of 350 children in 34 schools was tested using a randomised controlled trial design. [¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"The intervention is designed to be delivered by teaching assistants. It involves staff training, a detailed set of lesson plans, and materials for three ten-week blocks of teaching.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]" to test whether the provision of the Nuffield Early Language Intervention improved the language and literacy skills of children with relatively low language abilities.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 38:\n[¬s]"TA training was divided into two events: one event for the nursery intervention, and another for the reception intervention prior to its start. A key difference between these training events was their duration: the nursery training lasted one day while the reception training took place over two days"\n"Training typically provided background information about early years\x92 language learning (for example, what it is, why it is important, and the theory and terminology associated with it) and an overview of the evaluation taking place.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 81:
[¬s]"Day 1. The first day o f each w eek’s activities included an introduction o f the author and an opportunity for the children to predict what the story w ould be about based upon the cover picture. Additionally, prior to reading the story, the teacher discussed story elem ents such as main characters and the main events o f the story. The teacher then[¬e]"', 'Page 82:
[¬s]"read the story, pausing briefly at the vocabulary words and defining them in context o f the story. After reading the story, the teacher asked comprehension questions focusing on the vocabulary words and main story events."
"D ay 2. On day two, the teacher again introduced the author and reminded the children o f the three vocabulary words. The teacher introduced a nonverbal gesture sym bolizing each target vocabulary word for the children to use each time they heard the words while the teacher read the story. After reading the story, the teacher showed the children pictures o f the vocabulary words and three additional pictures from the same category per vocabulary word and discussed similarities and differences stressing how all are from the same category. For instance, the target word ”elk”, from the category o f “animal” was compared/contrasted with pictures o f “deer”, “horse”, and “m oose”. Categories and supplementary words used in the study are included in Appendix B. D ay 3. On day three, still using the same storybook, the children were asked to retell the story using the pictures in the book and to incorporate the three vocabulary words for the story. Prior to beginning the retell, the teacher asked students to state the three target vocabulary words and their meanings. After the children took turns retelling the story events, the teacher asked review-oriented questions focusing attention on the vocabulary words as related to the story elem ents o f beginning, m iddle, end, story problem, and problem solution. Day 4. D ay four consisted o f having the children act out the story events. Again, the teacher began the activity by asking children to state the three vocabulary words and their meanings. The teacher then selected students to play the various roles in the story[¬e]"', 'Page 83:
[¬s]"instructing the remaining students that they w ill be the directors in the audience to help the actors remember the events o f the story. The teacher and students guided the acting, making certain to incorporate the target words in the performance. Sample lesson plans for each day’s activities from the storybook, A bivovo. are included in Appendix C.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 80:\n[¬s]"The SAIL Intervention consisted o f storybook activities targeting vocabulary, comprehension, and narrative ability. The primary goal o f the activities was vocabulary development. Secondary language objectives were comprehension and narrative ability.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 90:\n[¬s]"One important component of the SAIL intervention was teacher training, as Head Start teachers implemented the intervention. Teachers completed an hour of training on implementing the SAIL intervention. The training included: a) a brief synopsis of the intervention rationale based upon the research literature, b) an overview of the three areas[¬e]"', 'Page 91:\n[¬s]"of language being targeted, c) the general structure of the storybook intervention, d) a description of the SAIL lessons, e) modeling of the SAIL intervention implementation including examples and non-examples, and f) an opportunity for practice with feedback. A copy of the training materials described above is located in Appendix I.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"the language arts approach was designed to utilize to the fullest children’s facility to com\xad municate through: oral language (speaking and listening); written language or dictation and creative writing; artistic ability in drawing and painting; and dramatic ability, creative dramatics, puppetry, and so on. Intensive word attack training was initiated from the beginning, using words derived from the chil\xad dren’s vocabulary both spoken and written. Group reading instruction to develop the thinking-reading skills required for reading for infor\xad mation was introduced by means of basic readers as soon as a group of children could read at a first reader level. When this stage of reading ability was attained, then reading instruction time was divided equally between group instruction using basic readers, individualized instruc\xad tion using self-selection from a li\xad brary, and creative writing.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 12:
[¬s]"The Language Arts Approach as used in this study is a method of reading instruction which utilizes the language skills of speaking, listening and writing to teach beginning reading. Through group and individually dictated accounts each child's unique oral language pat\xad terns and vocabulary are used to build individual reading materials through which initial sight vocabulary and word attack skills are developed. Creative writing, where each child writes his own ac\xad counts, and wide reading of a variety of materials arc an integral part of the program. The Language Arts Approach is characterized by a variety of grouping schemes for instructional purposes, including much work with children individually.[¬e]"', 'Page 46:
[¬s]" Pupils in the LAA classrooms were introduced to reading instruction by means of group and individually pupil-dictated accounts."
"Words recognized and remembered in the stories after at least 24 hours were placed on small cards and filed in a pupil's individual word bank. The words in the word bank formed the basis for the pupil's own sight vocabulary and were used to compose simple phrases, sentences and stories. The words were also used to develop and refine word attack skills.[¬e]"', 'Page 47:
[¬s]"As facility in word recognition skills increased and children acquired larger sight vocabularies, individually dictated accounts were exchanged among the pupils."
"Children also located words learned from their own storias in other materials such as news\xad papers, magazines and books."
" As reading vocabulary increased, children were encouraged to read pre-primers and trade books independently. This led directly to individualized directed reading-thinking acti\xad vities with the library as the source of materials. The use of the classroom and central school library was of major importance."
"As soon as handwriting facility was acquired, approximately 50-70 known words were accumulated in a child's word bank, and stable phoneme-grapheme relationships were mastered, each child was encouraged to write his own accounts.[¬e]"', 'Page 48:
[¬s]"When a sufficient reading vocabulary had been acquired to per\xad mit the use of basic readers at a first reader level, group Directed Reading-Thinking Activities were introduced. In the group Directed Reading-Thinking Activities, emphasis was placed on pupil purpose setting, reading to find answers to support or reject pupil conjec\xad tures, oral reading to prove answers, and problem or plot solving type reading.[¬e]"']

[¬s]"The LAA is an attempt to integrate the basic language arts areas of listening, speaking, reading and writing.[¬e]"']

strand_raw: ['Extending school time', 'Small group tuition', 'Oral language interventions']
int_desc_ht: ['Page 8:\n[¬s]"Chatterbooks is an extracurricular reading initiative designed and delivered by the Reading Agency (http://readingagency.org.uk) that aims to increase a child’s motivation to read by providing schools with tools and resources to encourage reading for pleasure and to widen the range of genres and authors that they are reading. It consists of weekly small-group sessions intended for six- to twelve- year-olds where attendance is voluntary. In general, the programme is run out of libraries and is flexible in terms of group size. For the purposes of this evaluation, delivery was altered significantly to test its impact in a more structured and formalised school environment. Chatterbooks Plus takes the basic Chatterbooks programme and replaces the last fifteen minutes of a normal session with dialogic reading where children read aloud and are offered explicit prompts.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 11:\n[¬s]" three groups: Chatterbooks and Chatterbooks Plus (intervention groups) and a waitlist control.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:\n[¬s]"to determine any impact on reading attainment both immediately after intervention delivery and at delayed post-test. It was also intended to determine whether, for the programme to be optimally effective in this age group and school context, the approach needed to be more structured and formalised for it to work.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht:
['Page 23:
[¬s]"The deliverers were randomised into two groups, with one group receiving training and delivering sessions just in Chatterbooks, and the other group concentrating solely on Chatterbooks Plus. The two strands of the intervention were delivered in each school, so deliverers were instructed not to mix between groups."
"Training consisted of a one-day course held at Coventry University in March 2013 and was run primarily by the Reading Agency and a representative from the Schools Library Service for Coventry. Professor Wood arrived towards the end of the day to conduct a Q&A session with delegates where she was able to clarify points from the morning’s research section of the training. All delegates were given a training pack on arrival, which consisted of the day’s programme, Chatterbooks ideas sheets, a Chatterbooks skills checklist (necessary skills for running Chatterbooks), a sheet of basic tips and a planning sheet. For Chatterbooks Plus the training pack also included a sheet detailing the required activities and structure of each session. Training for Chatterbooks was attended by 20 delegates made up of research assistant deliverers and teachers from the schools participating in the project, with the majority being teachers. Teachers were invited as an incentive for schools to take part in the project. For Chatterbooks Plus, there were four delegates only – the deliverers; no teaching staff were invited as Chatterbooks Plus is not endorsed by the Reading Agency. The delegates were not made aware in the training that this was not the original format of Chatterbooks. The concept of Chatterbooks was introduced, including several case studies of children in current groups around the country whose enthusiasm for reading has increased owing to their involvement in the scheme. There was also discussion about the desired outcomes of Chatterbooks, that these would be measured using an unspecified reading test, and how to achieve them. In the afternoon, the training focused on the outline of a single Chatterbooks session. The majority of the afternoon was given over to planning, with delegates working in groups to create session plans.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"The programme was delivered by trained graduates at Coventry University who had received training from the Reading Agency and Professor Clare Wood (for the dialogic reading component)[¬e]"']
int_who_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]"Both programmes were delivered by graduates at Coventry University hired specifically for this purpose.[¬e]"']
int_cost_ht: ['Page 7:\n[¬s]"Chatterbooks training costs £1,000 per session for 20 people. A ‘Chatterpack’ for each child costs £5. For a school that trains 20 people and provides the Chatterbooks programme to 150 pupils, the cost will be between £10 and £20 per pupil depending on the amount of supply cover used. The lowest figure in this estimate is based on a non-teaching member of staff delivering the intervention and therefore not requiring cover.[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Vocabulary Enrichment Full Programme combined three existing programmes – the Vocabulary Enrichment Intervention Programme (VEIP), Sounds-Write and Literacy Plus[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 11:
[¬s]"The VEIP is a structured scheme to teach children new words, and to encourage them to use these words in speaking and writing. It seeks to achieve these aims by cultivating children’s enthusiasm for words, and teaching them specific strategies for learning and recalling new vocabulary independently"
"he theory behind using VEIP as the main component of the intervention was that it would improve reading comprehension by: extending vocabulary; developing understanding of words in context, such as how sentence construction affects meaning and the use of different tenses, plurals etc.; and developing understanding of non-literal language."
"Sounds-Write is a phonics programme that follows a structured and cumulative sequence of teaching and learning."
" It was intended that the Sounds-Write training would ensure that teachers had the understanding of phonics necessary to deliver VEIP effectively.[¬e]"', 'Page 12:
[¬s]"Literacy Plus, devised by a previous UK government, is a scheme developed for Key Stage 3 lower attainers to facilitate progress from Level 3 to Level 4 "
" Literacy Plus was chosen for the intervention as it was felt to offer reading context that was firmly based in the national curriculum for English, and therefore would be a suitable complement to VEIP[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"Existing class teachers in the schools received training on all three elements and delivered the intervention to Year 7 pupils who had not reached a secure Level 4 in English at the end of Key Stage 2. The intervention replaced these pupils’ usual English lessons for three consecutive half terms between September 2013 and February 2014 (approximately 19 teaching weeks). The frequency and length of lessons depended on the schools’ individual timetabling arrangements.[¬e]"', 'Page 8:
[¬s]"The Vocabulary Enrichment Full Programme (VEFP) is a combination of the Vocabulary Enrichment Intervention Programme (VEIP, developed by Dr Victoria Joffe), the Literacy Plus scheme (developed by a previous UK government), and the Sounds-Write scheme (developed by qualified teachers Susan Case, David Philpot and John Walker). The three schemes differ from one another in terms of the emphasis placed on the development of reading, writing, speaking and listening skills. The combined intervention aimed to emphasise the development of literacy skills, in particular reading comprehension (the outcome measure). Schools were encouraged to use the three elements, with VEIP being the core element, to build their own scheme of work for low-attaining Year 7 pupils who were randomly selected to participate in the trial.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 9:\n[¬s]"What is the impact of the Vocabulary Enrichment Full Programme (VEFP) on reading ability? 7. Are improvements in attainment moderated by National Curriculum reading level or whether a pupil receives the pupil premium? The purpose of the process evaluation was to assess the intervention in terms of fidelity to the programme intentions and the scalability of the programme.[¬e]"']

" delegates were guided through the programme folder and worked in pairs to role-play the sessions."

"training aims to improve teachers’ knowledge and awareness of speech, language and communication difficulties.[¬e]"', 'Page 25:

int_name_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Vocabulary Enrichment Intervention Programme (VEIP) and the Narrative Intervention Programme (NIP)[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 6:
[¬s]"The VEIP and the NIP had not previously been evaluated for their impact on reading comprehension. They had been trialled in a three-armed trial undertaken by the developer of the two programmes in 21 secondary schools in outer London areas from 2006. The developer reported a significant impact of the VEIP on vocabulary test scores and of the NIP on storytelling skills, although the full analysis and report has not yet been published. The present study represents the first evaluation of the speaking and listening intervention in terms of its impact on reading ability. As the delivery was overseen by the trial developers, it can be regarded as an efficacy trial.[¬e]"', 'Page 7:
[¬s]"The speaking and listening intervention comprised two programmes delivered sequentially. The Vocabulary Enrichment Intervention Programme (VEIP) aims to teach children new words and encourage the use of these words in speaking and writing; the Narrative Intervention Programme (NIP) aims to enhance the understanding and expression of narratives to develop speaking and listening skills."
" It involved 352 pupils aged 12 who had achieved Level 4c or below in Key Stage 2 English and who had speech, language and communication difficulties (SLCD).[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]" The aim was to enhance pupils’ literacy by improving their vocabulary and narrative skills.[¬e]"']

"Each TA received a folder for each programme which contained the session plans and objectives, additional teaching notes, and session materials (such as template word maps and picture prompts), some of which are included on an accompanying DVD so that they can be used on a projector or interactive whiteboard. Schools were required to provide dictionaries, thesauruses, a microphone (not necessarily a real or functioning one), personal folders for pupils and various everyday objects as discussion stimuli.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"Five Teaching Assistants (TAs) and one teacher in the three secondary schools received training on the VEIP, the NIP and speech, language and communication difficulties.[¬e]"']

clust_anal_ht: ['Page 13:\n[¬s]"A single-level regression model was employed and this represents a slight deviation from the protocol where it was specified that a multi-level model would be used. Because randomisation was restricted by school, it was necessary to account for school in the model but this was done using dummy variables rather than by using a multi-level model. This method was preferred as a multi-level model would not have estimated variance adequately with only three schools. As this was a pupil- randomised trial, clustering for the intervention effect is not an issue in terms of internal validity.[¬e]"']

['Page 4:
[¬s]"The goals of the Language Experi\xad ence Approach are to help the child discover that thought can be represented in print, to capi\xad talize on the motivation and interest associated with actual events in the child’s life, and to min\xad imize decoding problems by using the child’s own language."
"The most important goal for this pro\xad ject was to help children see that written lan\xad guage is functional: that it can serve real and meaningful purposes for them, and that being able to use written language makes certain things easier, or even possible. A second goal was to help children understand some of the technical and arbitrary aspects of print: to facili\xad tate, through discovery, understanding of con\xad cepts such as "word,’’ "letter," and “sound,”[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"A third goal was to help children understand the need to be explicit when using written language."
" A fourth goal was to help children develop an awareness of text as a source of information and authority[¬e]"']

int_fidel_ht: ['Page 13:\n[¬s]"Teachers in the project were rated accord\xad ing to a checklist of characteristics of a language- and print-rich classroom. Raters disagreed on their ratings of only one teacher; one rater placed her in the nonimplemcnting category, and the other rated her as implement\xad ing the program to a limited degree. Ten of the participating teachers (77%) implemented the curriculum to some degree, and 6 (46%) did so effectively. Even if we include the teacher on whom raters disagreed, only 3 teachers (23%) were rated as nonimplementers. If the “limited degree" (C) and “not implemented" (D) catego\xad ries are collapsed, it would appear that over the course of the curriculum implementation, teachers were split about evenly between those who tried to implement components on a lim\xad ited scale or not at all, and those who adopted the components to implement an effective lan\xad guage- and print-rich environment.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 129:
[¬s]"1. The first step of this procedure is to select a topic. For this story, the topic selection is: MOOSE. 2. The teacher should then write the word, MOOSE, at the top of the chalkboard in big, bold letters. At this point, the teacher should point to the word and ask the students if anyone knows what that word is. When someone responds by reading the word, MOOSE, the teacher should indicate that this was an appropriate response, (i.e., Sue, that was right. You have done very well.) The teacher should then ask the students if anyone knows what a moose is? (Allow a few minutes for oral classroom discussion, then if the students are unable to provide the appropriate answer - you should tell the students that a moose is a "large animal, that looks like a deer with antlers but is larger."[¬e]"', 'Page 130:
[¬s]"3. Tell them to think about this word, moose, for a few seconds. 4. Tell them that you would like for them to think about all the words that remind them of a moose (i.e., teacher could say, for example, when I see the word moose, I think of the word, deer). Write your response on the board. 5. Pause for a few minutes to allow the students time to think about your response. 6. Then ask the students to raise their hands when they have a word that they would like for you to add to the list. Words that you want to be included in this list are: stomach, throat, tongue, forehead, better, four, breakfast, hungry, and hairy (see part 8). 7. Students' should generate enough words to allow for grouping, (i.e., 15-20 words would be adequate). 8. In the event that the class might fail to include the necessary words, you may wish to lead them into the inclusion of these words through the following cues (tell[¬e]"', 'Page 131:
[¬s]"students that these are words they will encounter when they, read their story about a moose)[¬e]"', 'Page 132:
[¬s]"9. Next, tell the students to look at the words and see if there is any way they could put these words into smaller groups? Give an example such as: tell them to look at the words throat and tongue; those two words could be put together. Ask if anyone knows why you might place these words in the same group (because they are both words that[¬e]"', 'Page 133:
[¬s]"indicate parts of the mouth). 10. Once you have placed these words into their respective groups, ask the students if they could give you a title for each small group of words. For example, the words tongue and throat might be given the title, "PARTS OF THE MOUTH". 11. Once you have completed this activity, the students should tell you why they chose the headings they did. Much of this may take place during #10, above, in that students may have to persuade their peers that their particular heading is appropriate and tell them why. At this time, you will wish to refresh their memories or to call on the child that solicited this response and ask them to refurnish their rationale for the selection of that title.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 17:\n[¬s]" An instructional strategy like list-group-label (LGL) focuses on the notion that not only can students\' vocabulary be broadened, but also through oral discussion each individual student can be given a broader view of the concept in question. The premise for the use of this activity is that a collaborative group effort will allow students the opportunity to express ideas and clear up any misconceptions that might be present prior to reading the text"\n" The effectiveness of each strategy, i.e., DRA, RRL, and LGL, will be investigated in terms of which approach might be most beneficial in activating prior knowledge for the purpose of improving vocabulary and comprehension in second grade subjects who are reading basal stories.[¬e]"']

int_training_ht: ['Page 10:\n[¬s]" A series of staff training sessions ran in every school at the start of each half term across the project (ten twilight training sessions in total). The training sessions were delivered by the SaLT and were designed for all staff to attend. Each training session focused on a different universal topic (e.g. supporting children\x92s listening, teaching vocabulary, supporting talk in the classroom). The aim of the training sessions was to introduce an area of language, to explain why it was important and to provide staff with practical strategies, approaches and resources for the classroom to embed support for communication across the curriculum. The SaLT worked with all class teachers following the training sessions, providing in-class mentoring and support as needed, to help get the strategies and resources up and running in every class to support all children\x92s communication development. \uf0b7 The universal programme for each school included an explicit focus on training staff in early identification so they could identify children who were struggling with their SLC development.[¬e]"']

int_name_info: Training programme word meaning derivation strategies
int_desc_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]"In the training program, students are taught in detecting cues in a text that can be used to find the meaning of an unfamiliar word. They are taught, step by step, to detect the following cues: An illustration, analysis of the word form (subdividing a word into parts, each with one\'s own meaning), a synonym, an antonym, and a description of the unfamiliar word in surrounding sentences. The training program is based on the principles of direct instruction (Pearson, & Fielding, 1991; Roehler, & Duffy, 1991) and reciprocal teaching (Palincsar, & Brown, 1984; Brown, & Palincsar, 1989). The program is conducted in small groups. In the first lessons, it is predominantly the teacher who demonstrates the strategy by thinking aloud. The teacher reads a paragraph aloud, stops at an unfamiliar word and shows how he or she goes about discovering the meaning of the word. The students are then allowed to comment on his or her description of the word\'s meaning. The students gradually take over the role of discussion leader.[¬e]"']
int_desc_info: Word meanings are derived through morphological analysis and the context  Students are taught to follow cues  an illustration, analysis of a word form, a synonym, an antonym, description of the unfamiliar word in surrounding sentences.

int_desc_ht:
['Page 5:
[¬s]"Two books by Frank Asch, Mooncake (1987) and Skyfire (1990), were chosen for the intervention "
"For each of the two books, the senior author of this study developed three sets of 25 scripted questions."
"The scripts were embedded in the books at the point at which the question was to be asked,"
"Some questions related to the text just read, and others were about a picture in the book. "
"The three different versions of questions were developed for each book to allow repeated readings of the same two stories while varying the questions asked in order to make the repeated readings more natural and to give the child experience with a wider range of both literal and inferential questions."
" All book-sharing sessions were video- and audio\xad recorded."
"The books with different sets of questions were numbered and read sequentially (e.g., Mooncake I, Mooncake 2, Mooncake 3) to the children to ensure that each version was read approximately the same number of times during the 8 weeks. A videotape of a session from each week of the intervention was jointly reviewed and discussed by the reader and one of the study authors to ensure treatment fidelity.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 69:
[¬s]"Vocabulary eliciting question condition. Vocabulary eliciting questions required each child to respond with novel target words from the story. The reader answered the question correctly when no response was given or an inaccurate response was stated by the child.[¬e]"', 'Page 72:
[¬s]"Storybooks and Novel Words. Three storybooks were designed so that the stories would be unfamiliar, but appropriate for 3-year-olds. Each storybook contained six novel target words in the text and six color illustrations, with samples of storybook illustrations shown in Figures 1,2, and 3 that accompanied each target word. See Appendices A, B,[¬e]"', 'Page 73:
[¬s]" The nine target novel words were: hearth, iceberg, lodge, rink, skis, snowcap, snowshoes, toboggan, and winterbourne. Each target word appeared once in two of the books.[¬e]"', 'Page 77:
[¬s]" In the Vocabulary Eliciting Question and the Noneliciting Question conditions, children were asked six questions per storybook. The questions were interspersed throughout the reading of the book. Participants’ responses to the questions were recorded in writing by the adult reader. Similar to Ard and Beverly’s (2004) methodology, if the child correctly responded, the experimenter provided mild affirmations, such as “okay” or “good” and then proceeded. After an exaggerated response time, if the child did not respond the investigator continued to read. In the event that the child asked or provided his or her own extratextual remarks, the experimenter neutrally responded (“hmmm”).[¬e]"', 'Page 81:
[¬s]"Intervention Session 4"
"Children were read all three stories with order counterbalanced. In this last intervention session, children heard each target word twice during story reading. As always, questioning exposure and target word usage was suited to the child’s reading intervention condition. For the Vocabulary Eliciting Question and the Noneliciting Question conditions, children were asked about each target word once, with a total of three questions to be asked during each story. [¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]" First, we wanted to optimize children’s opportunities for learning vocabulary from book reading. This goal was accomplished by having children"
"encounter the focal vocabulary multiple times and in multiple contexts beyond the pages of the book."
"Second, it was important to make target vocabulary salient so that children in groups of 12 to 15 could benefit from the instruc\xad tion. This goal was accomplished by providing children with concrete representations of the words and having the children encounter similar words in different books."
"Third, on the basis of Whitehurst’s work, we provided teachers with book reading strategies that emphasized open-ended ques\xad tioning and invited dialogue with children."
"The intervention consisted of training teachers in interactive book read\xad ing techniques and book reading extension activities as well as providing the necessary books and materials for the activities. The first part of the intervention began with training the teachers in interactive book reading strategies. This training consisted of instruction in (a) defining vocabulary words and providing opportunities for the children to use vocabulary from[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"the books , (b) asking open-ended questions and allowing children to talk beyond a “yes” or “no" response, and (c) providing children with oppor\xad tunities to talk and to be heard.[¬e]"']

clust_anal_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"A third analytical decision related to the fact that each teacher taught an a.m. and a p.m. class. When classroom means are the unit of analysis, each teacher would contribute two means if time of day were ignored, as preliminary analyses suggested that it should be. To avoid this dependency problem, we conducted an ANOVA comparing treatment and control classrooms for just the a.m. classes and an ANOVA comparing treatment and control class\xad rooms for just the p.m. classes. The expected result was a Treatment X Trial interaction if the intervention was effective (i.e., no difference in PPVT-III scores at the pretest but a significant difference at the posttest)"
" The analyses with classroom as the unit of analysis revealed the expected interaction for both the a.m. classes, F(l, 2) = 62.73, p< .016, and p.m. classes, F(l, 2) = 346.08, p < .001. The means were 73.66 (treatment) and 72.01 (control) for PPVT scores at the pretest and 81.30 (treatment) and 72.10 (control) for PPVT scores at the posttest. The comparable analyses with students as the unit of analysis produced the same Treatment X Trial interaction, F(l, 120) = 13.69, p < .001."
"A similar approach was used to examine treatment effects on the receptive and expressive vocabulary posttest measures constructed for this study. With classroom as the unit of analysis, the ANOVAs for the receptive measures revealed significant main effects of condition for both the a.m. classes, F(l, 2) = 133.940, p < .007, and p.m. classes, F(l, 2) = 293.68, p < .003. The means for the receptive measure were 37.85 (treatment) and 28.09 (control) for the a.m. classes and 38.05 (treatment) and 26.06 (control) for the[¬e]"']

int_name_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]" the intensive language and literacy intervention[¬e]"']
int_desc_ht:
['Page 1:
[¬s]" train teachers how to increase opportunities for language and vocabulary development in young children[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]"allowed children to have multiple encounters with vocabulary words from a book reading. Teachers from Title I preschools were trained in a series of questioning strategies similar to dialogic reading, which focused on asking open-ended questions, providing descriptions of unfamiliar vocabulary, and relating the book and vocabulary to children\x92s experiences. In addition, teachers had props that represented the vocabulary words that they were focus- ing on from the storybook. To create opportunities for vocabulary use beyond the book reading class experience, we designed art and"
"other center-related activities so that (a) the activities were related to the books, (b) the activities provided a natural context for both the teacher and child to use the book-related vocabulary words, and (c) the teacher was trained to use the vocabulary multiple times throughout the activities. [¬e]"', 'Page 4:
[¬s]"The intervention model focused on training teachers in book reading and oral language strategies. Teachers were also provided with 22 prop boxes that included books, concrete objects that represented target words in the books, and lesson plans. The props and books were used as part of the book reading and oral language activities.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 3:\n[¬s]"The present study had several goals. The first goal was to determine whether the intensive language and literacy intervention designed by Wasik and Bond (2001) would have a similar effect in settings comprising Head Start teachers and primarily disadvan- taged children. The second goal was to determine whether training could influence how teachers talked to children. Third, in addition to focusing on book reading, the current intervention trained teach- ers to use discourse strategies that tend to increase oral language opportunities for children at other times during the school day. Using discourse strategies in activities other than book reading is essential for language development. The fourth goal of the study was to determine whether the impact of the intervention could be generalized when larger samples of teachers are involved. Finally, in addition to determining whether the Wasik and Bond approach could be effective in Head Start contexts, we conducted explor- atory analyses of possible linkages between teacher behaviors and outcomes.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht:
['Page 4:
[¬s]"Teachers were trained in three components of the book reading module: (a) asking questions, (b) building vocabulary, and (c) making connections. In asking questions, teachers were trained to ask open-ended questions that would elicit more than a one-word response.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]" The training schedule began with the oral language module and continued with the book reading module. A group training with all of the intervention teachers was conducted once a month for 2 hr. During that time, teachers were trained in the explicit oral language and book reading strategies. The training focused on explaining what the strategy was, why it was important to use, and how it could be adapted in the classroom. Within 1 week of the training, Mary Alice Bond and Annemarie Hindman modeled the strategy that was discussed during the group training in each teacher\x92s classroom. The teachers were then given 2 weeks to practice the strategy. "
"This coaching model was used to ensure that the teacher understood how to master the strategy and was able to use it flexibly in various situations"
"On average, Head Start teachers received a minimum of 2 hr of direct coaching per month.[¬e]"']
int_dur_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]" 9-month period, from the end of September to the beginning of June.[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"For the school reading condition, the teacher or aide engaged in dia- logic book reading with children in groups of no more than 5 children at a time. Shared reading sessions were scheduled to occur daily for about 10 min per reading group. Six to eight ofthe books listed in Table 2 were used in any particular classroom over the 6-week intervention. The books in Table 2 were chosen primarily because of their potential to support vocabulary growth. Each had illustrations that could serve as a basis for introducing new vocabulary to the child, and each could support a story narrative through the illustrations alone. "\n"The selection of books for a particular classroom from those in Table 2 depended primarily on availability from the sup- plier. We excluded from use in any classroom any book that children had previously encountered in their day-care center.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht: ['Page 2:\n[¬s]" We hypothesized that children who were read to by teachers in day care would[¬e]"', 'Page 3:\n[¬s]"show increments in language ability compared with a control group[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]"Teachers were trained to read to children in a dialogic reading style by using a videotape training method (Arnold et al., 1994; Whitehurst, Arnold, & Lonigan, 1990) modeled closely on our previously used di- rect training procedures (Valdez-Menchaca & Whitehurst, 1992; Whitehurst, Falco, et al., 1988). The videotape contained two assign- ments, described in Table 3. The procedures for the adult in Table 3 were presented as a set of rules and were followed by taped vignettes of adult-child book reading that exemplified those rules. Afinalsection of the videotape consisted of vignettes of inappropriate adult-child book reading. Teachers were asked by the trainer to criticize the readers in the vignettes in terms of the rules of dialogic reading and to indicate what the adult reader should have done differently in response to the child. Following the videotape, the trainer engaged in role play with the teach- ers being trained, which involved presenting various examples of child behavior and giving the teacher feedback on her use ofthe dialogic read- ing rules. The whole training sequence took about 30 min per trainee for Part 1 and 20 min for Part 2. Part 1 and Part 2 training were sepa- rated by 3 weeks. Teachers were trained during the school da[¬e]"']
int_freq_ht: ['Page 4:\n[¬s]" Shared reading sessions were scheduled to occur daily[¬e]"']

int_desc_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"The complete curriculum will be an integrated and interlocking set of novels with each carrying different specific philosophic content; yet each will reinforce the basic skills of logical thinking, mean\xad ing acquisition, language analysis, and reflective thinking. Harry stresses formal, syllogistic reasoning;"
"The title of each novel is the name of one of the characters in the stories. The children form a community of inquirers in their class\xad room as they discover the rules of logic, discuss good reasons for behaving in certain ways, try to determine the meaning of concepts such as fairness, the mind, culture, right and wrong, and other classical philosophic ideas. Thus, the novels serve the dual function of carrying the content of philosophy and logic while pro\xad viding a model of good dialogue and reflective thinking.[¬e]"', 'Page 5:
[¬s]"The teachers used Harry Stottlemeier's Discovery (Lipman, 1977) weekly for one forty-five minute period as a supplement to the regular reading program with the experimental groups. Most of the classes completed ten chapters, approximately, one-half of the book, during the school year.[¬e]"']
int_objec_ht:
['Page 2:
[¬s]"While the materials developed by the Institute are not designed to teach reading, they do attempt to improve skills which are directly related to, and should be included in, any reading program.[¬e]"', 'Page 3:
[¬s]" formal and informal logic skills and reflective thinking will contribute to improved reading comprehension,"
" However, none of these studies has addressed the effects of the materials on children reading below grade level. Further, results of studies with students reading above grade level have been mixed. In the present Investigation there was an attempt to examine the effects of philosophy for children on the reading achievement of both these groups.[¬e]"']
int_training_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"The four teachers volunteered to participate in the program. They attended an intensive one-week workshop prior to the opening of school during which the logic and philosophic content of Harry Stott!emeier\'s Discovery (Lipman, 1977) was studied, both by demonstration with children and by philosophical discussions. Teachers were given opportunities to lead discussions over the content of Harry and to practice some of the exercises in the teacher\'s manual with children. During the year the teachers were further trained in regular monthly seminars.[¬e]"']
int_dur_ht: ['Page 5:\n[¬s]"Most of the classes completed ten chapters, approximately, one-half of the book, during the school year.[¬e]"']
